name: Nicola BEER
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the oral question to the Commission on the 'From farm to the table' strategy – the important role of farmers and rural areas by Norbert Lins on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development (O-000013/2020 – B9-0009/2020) (2020/2542(RSP)). You know that you can continue to submit your spontaneous speeches and your intermediate questions to us both with the card and electronically.

name: Norbert LINS
text: Author. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has Agriculture is passion. Agriculture is not just a profession like any other where you do your job, do your job and just want to bring a bit of money home to feed the family. No – farmers have a mission: they want to produce the best quality, sustainable food, and they are already doing so today. They want to equip consumers with the best food, and they want to develop their own farm and they want to develop it so that they can pass it on to the next generation. Often we have stories of generations, sometimes centuries, where people on the same farms cultivate the same area for generations. Let me just use my own story to tell you the passion behind it. I am now 42 and I have been working for over 30 years, and mainly because I worked with my parents on my own farm from a young age: feeding the calves, milking the cows, taking the manure fork in my hand – simply helping to ensure that this farm has a future, that this farm continues to make it possible to produce the best food. I tell you, sometimes it was hard when the others went to the swimming pool in the summer and I had to get on the tractor, help to get the harvest. But I also tell you that it was possible not only because passion was there, but also because there was recognition, because there was appreciation, because I realized that there is respect in the village because of what we can do, what our company can do. And it is precisely this respect, the recognition, the appreciation – which are increasingly lacking. We must be careful in our political debates on agriculture that we do not pillory farmers, we do not talk about polluters, about climate killers, about poison mixers, but that we talk to them, that we tell them: yes, you are doing a great job, but we need to get better. And that we are enabling them to get better, that we do not launch a ban in the next few months, that we do not launch a conditional in the next few months, but that we are incentivising more climate protection: that, for example, we enable farmers to build up humus for more climate protection; that we will enable them to use fewer plant protection products – but with incentives, with the right measures, and not with bans. That we should enter into the debate on how we protect our farmers beyond the European Union – when we already have the highest environmental requirements in Europe. This is also a question that must be asked. How do we manage, Commissioner, for the rest of us to follow us in the world? So that we are developing trade agreements, for example, from product standards to production standards, this is also an issue that needs to be put at the centre.  There is another question at the heart of this agricultural debate and this debate on the farm-to-fork strategy: it must also be about the consumer. If we want to shape this transformation process, we need nothing less than a consumer turnaround. If, in my country, 72% of consumers say: yes, I am prepared to put more money on the table for more animal welfare, for more environmental protection, for more climate protection – 72%!, – but only 16% at the counter are actually prepared to pay more, then there is something wrong. So one is politics, also at European level, but the other is also the consumer and the consumer in Europe – they too must be prepared to pay more. Let us take the farmers with us. I had five farmers' meetings last weekend – I can tell you, Commissioner, that there are great concerns that farmers are being cornered, and we have to organise the opposite, take them with them in this debate, say: 'You are not part of the problem, you are part of the solution'. That is why it is right that this debate should take place today in the centre of this House, on prime time; that we are getting agriculture exactly where it belongs – at the heart of the debate – now that the farm-to-fork strategy is published.

name: Janusz WOJCIECHOWSKI
text: Member. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I thank President Lins and the Members of the Committee on Agriculture for organising this very important and necessary debate, which our farmers in particular are waiting for.  The field-to-table strategy has not yet been adopted by the European Commission. Work is ongoing and a communication is due at the end of March. However, the main objectives of this strategy have already been identified in the Communication on the European Green Deal. This is an ambitious plan to introduce a sustainable food production system, and European farmers have a key role to play in this plan. The strategic plans will have to reflect more ambitious targets including a significant reduction in the use of chemical pesticides as well as fertilisers and antibiotics. Organic farming and precision farming are to be developing. Stricter animal welfare standards are to be introduced. The quality of soil, water and air is expected to improve. European farmers therefore face a great challenge: producing food in a sustainable way, for the benefit of the environment, climate and human health. This is an ambitious challenge, but it is also costly. Farmers cannot stay alone with this challenge. The European Union must help them, we all need to help them. Less than 10 million European farmers provide food security for more than 500 million until recently, now 450 million of our citizens. We should thank them for this every day. Thank you for being there, that they want to work on their farms, that they want to take care of the land and animals. There are fewer and fewer those who want to do this. We have a big problem in the European Union of farms without successors and depopulation of rural areas.  Food security is as important as defence or energy security. In order to ensure food security, we must take care of our farmers and create decent living conditions for them. This is a task for the common agricultural policy, but also for other EU policies. I would like to thank you very much for the key questions raised in this debate. How will the Commission ensure that people living in the countryside, including farmers but also processors, remain the most important and future challenges taken into account? How will the Commission ensure the competitiveness of Union producers and guarantee a fair income for farmers in the context of additional requirements resulting from new and revised policies? Such questions are also asked by the farmers themselves. I have recently had the opportunity to meet farmers in various EU countries: Croatia, Germany, Austria and Poland. I am now going to meetings with farmers in France and then to more countries. I also meet with representatives of many agricultural organisations from Europe.  Farmers are aware of the need to move to a sustainable way of producing food. If at present part of agricultural production does not meet the conditions for sustainability, if we are dealing, for example, with concentration and intensification of farming, it is not because farmers wanted it, but because economic circumstances forced them to do so. Simply to sustain themselves from their farms, farmers had to increase the scale and intensity of production. But now we need to help farmers change this so that agriculture becomes agriculture again, not turned into an industry. We will not achieve the objectives of the European Green Deal and the field-to-table strategy by coercion against farmers (I fully agree with what President Lins said). We can only achieve these goals through reasonable assistance. This aid is, above all, an adequate budget for the common agricultural policy, appropriate to the challenges facing our agriculture. A strong and fair-divided budget. I am very pleased that awareness of the need for such a budget exists not only in the Commission and in the European Parliament, but also in the Member States. I was very pleased with the joint declaration by the three Agriculture Ministers: Mrs Klöckner from Germany, Mr Glavany from France, Mr Planas from Spain. In this declaration, ministers are firmly in favour of the need to strengthen the budget of the common agricultural policy. On 27th January a majority of ministers from the other Member States expressed a similar view at the Council meeting, which are also in favour of the need to strengthen the budget of the common agricultural policy. And I am also in favour of that. We need a strong, fair budget for the common agricultural policy.  The ambitious challenges posed by the European Green Deal and the field-to-table strategy must have financial security. There must be adequate resources for eco-programmes in the first pillar. This is particularly the case for countries which have a low level of direct payments and are seeking to compensate them. There must be adequate resources for action on the environment, climate and animal welfare in the second pillar. These, in turn, need countries with lower rural development funds.  We will encourage farmers to apply sustainable farming practices, sustainable farming practices, for example to reduce the intensity of farming, to voluntarily introduce higher animal welfare standards, but we must have adequate budgetary resources to do so. It is my duty to talk about this, especially now that the time for important policy decisions on the Multiannual Financial Framework is approaching. This case also has a dignity dimension. We will only achieve the objectives of the European Green Deal and the field-to-table strategy if we treat farmers with dignity. Not as a problem to be tackled, but as partners in the implementation of socially important tasks. I am sure that we will receive the full support and commitment of farmers to the historical challenges we face. Dear! European agriculture must be sustainable, environmentally friendly, climate and animal welfare, but in order to achieve this, agricultural policy must be farmer-friendly, ambitious and fair.

name: Herbert DORFMANN
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. It is good that we have this debate today; we had to fight for it. It is true, I have the impression, that some believe that this farm-to-fork strategy could either be developed past the farmers or perhaps even against the farmers. I think we are very glad that you are here today, Commissioner, but the fact that Executive Vice-President Frans Timmermans is not here today also shows that this thinking is certainly there in the Commission. I venture a prognosis: if we do not actively involve the farmers in this debate, then this strategy will go against the wall. Driving against the wall – I dare say that. And I think that at the moment it is just the case that the farmers seem to be responsible for everything: for the loss of biodiversity, for climate change, for the excessive use of chemicals, for the excessive use of antibiotics. The reality on the ground is completely different. The vast majority of farmers must see that they continue to get their farms, get on economically, find successors, and they usually think much more sustainably than many, many other actors in our economic cycles. They produce food; and consumers are constantly claiming that they want things even better, want them even healthier, want even more sustainable, and as soon as they go to the supermarket, they are looking for the offer where they can pay one and take three with them. That just doesn't work in this form. There is, of course, a lot to improve. I am also convinced that the strategy makes sense. You can think about plant protection, you have to think about fertilisation, but you have to do it with a hope for progress, with a hope for innovation and research, for more knowledge. This is the only way we will ultimately meet these challenges.  Overall, I believe that we need an alliance: we need an alliance with the farmers, we need to take the farmers with us. My group stands for this path, we want to go through this strategy together with the farmers. Then it will be successful.

name: Paolo DE CASTRO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, without the firm participation of our farmers, any prospect of climate change mitigation becomes unachirredable. That is why today we need a highly common approach to defining the future agricultural policy, which must remain European. And this Parliament, Commissioner, must not miss the opportunity to integrate key elements of the Farm to Fork strategy into a CAP that will point the way for European agriculture over the next decade. The agri-food sector is ready to get involved in providing even more environmental services, achieving carbon neutrality for the benefit of all European citizens. However, these efforts will have to be matched not only by incentives through a properly funded CAP, but above all by the availability of innovative production techniques, including those of varietal improvement which are capable of replacing chemistry in protecting plant health. There is no environmental sustainability without the economic and social sustainability of the sector. We have before us a huge challenge, which we can only overcome thanks to a renewed role for the European Union.

name: Dacian CIOLOŞ
text: on behalf of the Renew group. – Madam President, Commissioner, yesterday in this Chamber we spoke about the future multiannual budget of the European Union and we insisted that this budget must be proportionate to the ambitions we have, with the priorities we have for the European Union. I said that we must not oppose traditional policies, such as the common agricultural policy, to the new priorities, Green Deal, to digital transformation.  And I think that's where we need to start: agriculture as an economic and societal objective is more current and modern than ever, but we need to have the courage to think about how we modernise it and how we put it in line with today's expectations and realities, both of farmers and consumers. Because a Green Deal, a green pact, has no chance in the European Union without the contribution of agriculture. But agriculture can't contribute more to society's expectations if we don't think about income for farmers.  We must therefore start from the expectation of consumers to have quality food, the expectation of citizens to have public services that ensure the proper management of natural resources, and for that we must find solutions so that farmers have a decent income.  And here, beyond the budget of the common agricultural policy, we need to think of an investment plan. And because of this, this 'farm to fork' strategy has no chance and no sense if we are talking only about pesticides, chemicals and only an isolated part of agricultural activity.  This "farm to fork" strategy should be a New Deal for agriculture and consumers. That's where we should start. From society's expectations of agriculture, from how we make better, more quality food, how we make agricultural practices, also using investment resources from the Green Deal and digital transformation, help farmers align with the expectations we have. Only under these conditions is a "farm to fork" strategy that has a utility.

name: Ivan DAVID
text: On the id group, Madam President, a very expensive database is being built to record information on European farmers, primary producers, food producers and retail chains. The costs will be borne by the EU Member States, the EU as such, but also by farmers, who will reflect the costs in prices and become less competitive themselves. A giant tunnel is digging through the Directorate-General for International Trade. This promotes increasing duty-free imports from third countries. There is no control and there will be no control. No one will force these countries to comply with European rules. Their organs won't require them. For example, cattle are processed on ships with complete exclusion of control.  New and new obligations are being imposed on European farmers, with more and more food being marketed from non-EU producers who do not have to pay such costs. These are legitimate claims of farmers, but also of consumers, including the prices they have to pay. It is unacceptable to import food from countries where compliance with the same conditions as must be applied in the EU cannot be guaranteed.

name: Sarah WIENER
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, Commissioner Wojciechowski, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. I am pleased that we are talking about Farm to Fork today, because that is important. We know that we have immense problems, otherwise we would all not be sitting here at all. This strategy is a historic opportunity to make the CAP more sustainable, to make it more climate-friendly, to finally promote the fight against the collapse of ecosystems, to focus on animal welfare and animal health and soil health. These are issues that we are all there for. Science is asking us to do so, and the people are asking us to do so. It is perhaps the last chance to really reform the CAP. Of course, the farmers are afraid, yes. But to entrench one's car castle mentality and say, "What about us, what about us?" and not to be part of the solution and not to be innovative and courageous ly not afraid of change, that will not help us. We can't hide and say, "That's how we've always done it, so it's good." We know that is not true. We are on an abyss, we need to change. And we must not only focus on the farmers, who are standing with their backs to the wall and are abolishing themselves, but we need the dignity of the farmer again, we need self-confidence. I don't want support, I want help for transformation, I want help for my own dignity, at fair food prices, that my profession is honored again and that I can live on it regardless of subsidies. That is why the CAP needs to be reformed. And now I have a question, Mr Wojciechowski: the case law of the European Court of Justice C-409/13 paragraph 74 shows that the Commission has the right to adapt its own legislative proposal during the codecision procedure until the Council has taken the final decision. Do you intend, this essential element of the CAP, to use this opportunity to reconcile the CAP drafts with the ambitions of the Green Deal? This has to happen.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. First of all, I would like to thank you very much for the thorough analysis you have carried out with regard to European agriculture when it is to be covered by two new strategies: the Green Deal and the field-to-table strategy. There is no doubt that both will result in new obligations and requirements for farmers, and probably production constraints, especially for industrial agriculture.  In this situation, the question is extremely topical: how to finance all this? It just so happens that the previous European Commission presented in May 2018 a draft budget that reduced CAP appropriations by 17%, which, in the light of the new challenges facing European agriculture, seems simply unacceptable. Moreover, the national strategic plans prepared by the Member States have already signalled the need to reduce mainly animal production in western European countries' most industrialised agriculture, which has sparked violent protests by farmers and the departure of tens of thousands of tractors to the streets of cities. In this situation, additional CAP funding must appear in the 2021-2027 budget negotiations, which will be distributed to all Member States in order to finance these two new strategies and to align direct payments with the EU average in central and eastern European countries.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Commissioner, European agricultural policy subsidizes large industrial farmers, locks up animals in mega-stables, forces farmers to scale unhealthily, unsustainable and unsustainable and unsustainable, causes enormous environmental pollution to the livestock industry with mega subsidies to the livestock industry, sends hundreds of small-scale farmers to the brink every day, drags millions of animals around the world under dire conditions and contributes to a huge biodiversity loss. It's a screwed-up system.  Farmers should be given a fair price for a fair product. Fair for animals, fair for the environment and fair for the climate. You don't do that with free trade agreements like Mercosur, CETA and TTIP light, which open the borders to cheap, dieron-friendly and environmentally unfriendly agricultural products. We need a change of course.  That is also why I believe that European agricultural subsidies should be abolished.

name: Dino GIARRUSSO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are very much awaiting the Farm to Fork plan, which is why I have some misgivings. The reduction of fertilizers, for example, is required only "if necessary", instead we believe it is an indisputable necessity. There is also no reference to the obligation to reduce food waste and to comply with European standards under the Green New Deal. We also call for a reference to sustainable single labelling, not the aberration of nutri-score but labelling that correctly indicates the nutritional aspects and the environmental and social impact of each product and that takes into account the importance of the farmer's work. Finally, we would like to see further support for organic farming, which will put the farmer at the centre of the process of environmental recovery and stress how organic can combat climate change, stimulate demand for organic products and accompany farmers to join the Farm to Fork. That is why I stress that it is our duty to secure the necessary funds for the CAP and then manage it intelligently, perhaps also taking advantage of the mistakes of the past.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Madam President, I hope this morning’s debate, Commissioner, is a wake—up call to the Commission and to this House that farmers are angry, frustrated, worried and under attack. They are one group of society that do not take well to this. The truth is that, in this issue of Farm to Fork, we do need farmers to be front and centre of it, not to be dragged kicking and screaming. Commissioner, I hope you’ll deliver that message to your colleagues around the table. I hope you’ll include in this Farm to Fork Strategy competition law, unfair trading practices, and how trade policy can impact negatively on European agriculture. I would just say that some of the language used, indeed by yourself and others in the Chamber, can be very emotive: organic is wonderful, factory intensive is evil. I’d like you to be a little bit more careful about the language, because many of our family farms can be medium—sized or they can be large, but it doesn’t suggest, whether small, medium or large, that one is better than the other. What we should be trying to do is make sure that farmers have access to the best research, the best innovation, and the best technologies to allow them to deliver on the things we need them to do. And let’s not forget that farmers are already doing it. They’ve been up before we have. They’re out in their farms and in their fields doing things for nature. We need to help them do that, not restrict them in their efforts. My greatest fear of CAP reform and this strategy is that we will bind them with more rules and give them less flexibility. Commissioner, you have a huge responsibility on your shoulders to make sure that doesn’t happen. I hope your voice is loud. (Applause)

name: Isabel CARVALHAIS
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I fully agree with you that the farm-to-fork strategy must be an ambitious strategy capable of responding very clearly to the challenges of environmental sustainability, human health, climate change and animal welfare. And the Commissioner certainly also agrees with me that this strategy must integrate respect and recognition for agricultural activity, by our farmers, by rural communities. The question is, how does this respect come to fruition? In other things, the response to the new challenges does not materialise without the effort of farmers and this means that they must be supported in a supportive, cohesive, fair way. The economic and social sustainability worthy of our farmers depends on the vitality of our rural communities. And so what I ask you, commissioner, and I hope this time to get a clearer answer, is how do you intend to articulate your vision for a long-term strategy for the development of rural communities with the farm-to-fork strategy? In other words, how do you consider that, in practice, one can ensure that the farm-to-fork strategy is designed and implemented in such a way as to address the true needs of the rural world?

name: Ulrike MÜLLER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has We are witnessing politics being put back on the streets. People are demonstrating for more climate protection and nature conservation. That is good and is heard here too and applauded. But when thousands of farmers demonstrate, who take to the streets because of excessive bureaucracy, a lack of appreciation and great fears of existence, this is hardly noticed here in Brussels. The whole situation is fuelled by our Vice-President, Mr Timmermans, who is making statements here about drastically reducing animal husbandry. I really wonder how this 40% grassland that we have within Europe will actually be managed and who will continue to cultivate it. Of course, we know that we all need to become more sustainable, that we need to do more for the environment. Agriculture is changing. This can only be achieved together, and that is why the farm-to-fork strategy must not lead to even more agricultural requirements and must be predictable for farmers. I call on you not to allow delays in the common agricultural policy through the Green Deal and the farm-to-fork strategy. We won't start until 2023 anyway. The legislative package is in place and we can incorporate elements into eco-schemes and also protect the environment. I do not want the saying that 'if the farmer is ruined, your food will be imported', Commissioner. There is much more at stake: it is about the survival interests of rural areas and agricultural families.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Madam President, the Von der Leyen Commission has announced its intention to set up a model of sustainable agriculture and food that respects the environment and consumers, which it has presented in the form of the slogan 'farm to fork'. I am being asked today to say what I think. The problem is that we do not have any specific documents detailing this project at this time. At most, there is a brief one-and-a-half page presentation in the Green Pact guidance document. As things stand, "farm to fork" is, in my view, a hollow slogan. In order to be constructive, I draw the Commission's attention to the need to harmonize its future proposals with the new Common Agricultural Policy, which is nearing completion. On the content of the project, it will not be enough to announce vague measures such as, I quote, "the significant decrease in pesticide use"; we will also have to find real solutions to the real problems. First, to guarantee our food sovereignty instead of sacrificing our agriculture on the altar of globalized free trade. Secondly, develop short circuits to break the oligopoly of retail purchasing power plants. Third, to facilitate the farming profession by simplifying the rules and red tape, which have become overwhelming. It is time to stop contenting ourselves with slogans and finally take action, because farmers and consumers are waiting for us.

name: Martin HÄUSLING
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner, you said an important sentence at the beginning of your speech: 'Agriculture must not become an industrial sector'. Yes, absolutely right – but then we must also adopt a different agricultural policy, because at the moment the big ones are benefiting from the payments. If we continue to distribute payments in this way, 70% without conditions, only in terms of area, then we will not be making any real environmental policy. If you are serious about the Green Deal and Farm to Fork strategies, I would be curious to see how you will end up incorporate this into this common agricultural policy. So far, the fact is that a conservative majority actually wants everything to continue like this, and a bit of greening all around. This cannot work, and ladies and gentlemen, it is about farmers, yes, but we have a massive problem with the loss of biodiversity. We cannot discuss this away. We are using too many pesticides, and the Court of Auditors has just said that we are having a disastrous policy in the field of pesticides. We have to get down from the large amounts of fertilisers, otherwise we will not be able to control the extinction of the species.  And, of course, in the Green Deal – and I agree with many people – we must also take into account the effects we are having for other countries with agricultural policy. That is why I say that if we adopt this Mercosur agreement in this way and continue to import the masses of soya, then it will also be a disaster for the environment. That is why trade policy must also change in this context. And, I say this, we must finally start to pursue a different animal welfare policy. It is not going to continue with mass animal husbandry, and that is why we urgently need to make corrections to this too.

name: Bert-Jan RUISSEN
text: Mr President, the challenges facing agriculture are immense: ensuring a high quality food, the landscape and biodiversity, with the lowest possible emissions. All this requires a modern agriculture that uses the latest insights, races and techniques. Fortunately, a lot is already happening in that area. Let us encourage and give space to these new developments, rather than frustrate them. The biggest pitfall of the "Farm to Fork" Strategy is to revisit it in a stacking of regulations, in the ill-considered banning of plant protection products for example, when there are no alternatives yet. I therefore call on the Commission to come up with good plans to reward the sector for its efforts and not to divert the resources needed for good business operations. I would like to say to the Commissioner: do not judge companies on the basis of the number of animals per holding, but on the basis of their environmental performance per unit of product. This could lead to very surprising new insights. (The speaker responds to a "blue card" question (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Antonius MANDERS
text: "blue card" question. Mr President, I would like to ask Mr Ruissen whether he has also thought about reducing food waste, because food waste – its total value – exceeds the European budget every year. If we focus on that, we don't have to give any more subsidies.

name: Bert-Jan RUISSEN
text: "blue card" answer. Mr President, that is certainly a very important issue that we must certainly work on. Reducing food waste in the various links of the chain is very important. I think we should work on that, too. That does not mean – I do not agree with you – that subsidies would not be necessary. For the time being, we just need those subsidies to help the sector make that change.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Madam President, a Farm to Fork Strategy, if done correctly and funded correctly, can be of great benefit to consumers and farmers alike. We can see a situation such as: labelling of meat such as beef, details of what the animal was fed, hours inside, carbon footprint, fertilisers used, price given to the farmer. This is an opportunity to differentiate between one type of beef or meat and another. Look at free range eggs. People currently go into a shop and they pay more for them. We can have the same thing with beef. The question is: how serious are the Commission about this, what money will they put into it? The Commissioner mentioned it’s as important as security and defence. I would say it’s more important. I would say it is security and defence. You look at the multiannual financial framework (MFF), you look at our priorities. We see a 22 times increase in funding for weapons and death, bombs and bullets. In the MFF we are choosing fighting before feeding. We need to reverse that if we want to fund this and be serious about it.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, the Farm to Fork strategy can be the mechanism by which several objectives are achieved: quality food, affordable prices or combating climate change.  However, the agricultural sector cannot be considered solely responsible for the decline of biodiversity or the depletion of natural resources. This responsibility we all have.  Farmers must be seen as part of the solution and in no way part of the problem in terms of combating climate change. The success of the Farm to Fork strategy depends on whether or not we are anchored in the reality on the ground and able to understand what the vulnerabilities are, but also the opportunities in this sector.  An eminently green policy, which does not take into account its ability to adapt to new conditionalities, will put pressure on both farmers and consumers, who will be forced to pay more for food. In the end, both consumers and farmers will lose. I do not want to imagine what a phenomenon like the Yellow Jackets from farmers across the European Union could mean. The Green Agreement and the Farm to Fork strategy must be turned into opportunities for agriculture if we are to really succeed.  However, there is a need for substantial funding from the Member States. One thing clearly needs to be understood: there is no more you can do with less money.  Access to research, precision agriculture as a guarantee of the sustainability of the agricultural sector must, however, be shared equally among farmers in the Member States.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: Madam President, from farm to fork, we must reason with short circuits, family farms, human-sized farms. From farm to fork, it brings the consumer closer to the producer, and this choice implies a reorientation of the agricultural model, so that farmers live decently from their trade and consumers benefit from quality products. From farm to fork, it also means putting in place measures to reduce food waste, which accounts for 25-30% of food production; it is further reducing the use of chemical pesticides and facilitating market access to organic substances and products.  So yes, the Green Pact must be a real opportunity for farmers and for rural people, and they must have a central role in this new economic model that is presented to us, and which is inevitable. And it is for this reason that the common agricultural policy must first and foremost support farmers in this transition. The whole thing, Commissioner, is to give ourselves the means of such an ambition and to finally overcome the effects of announcement.

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: Mr President, for decades we have had a common agricultural policy that is not working properly at the moment. The European Court of Auditors is also very critical of this. What's that about? The greening measures we have in the common agricultural policy are being made generic here in Brussels and farmers simply have to implement them. It is only checked whether the farmer actually implemented that measure. It does not look at what the actual result is. I am very pleased that the previous Commission has put forward a proposal to test the actual result, to give farmers the space for things they are good at, namely entrepreneurship and innovation, to ensure that they are motivated and to encourage that entrepreneurship in order to actually get that greening off the ground. , and to reward the results of farmers in a good way. Then it's going to work. Take, for example, how the electric car has become extremely popular throughout Europe. It happened exactly the same way. What I am very afraid of now is that with this 'Farm to Fork' Strategy we are going back to the old policy, that we are only going to reintroduce measures from Brussels top-down that a farmer cannot get away with at all. Include the goals of the Green Deal in the common agricultural policy. Focus on results. Reward for results.  What we need to do in a Farm-to-Fork strategy is look at rules that don't work well. It is ridiculous that, for example, insect meal can still not be used in animal feed. It is ridiculous that there are very few alternatives to low-risk resources to do crop protection. It is ludicrous that the nitrate directive still promotes fertilizer in relation to animal manure. And it is ridiculous that innovations in the field of breeding are still not possible.

name: Gianantonio DA RE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Commission has presented the strategy called 'From fields to the table', which envisages making the European agri-food system a global reference model in terms of sustainability. These are the objectives: to continue to ensure a high level of safety in agricultural products, production and marketing, to ensure a fair income for farmers, to safeguard biodiversity and, finally, to reduce dependence on pesticides. I ask myself: will products imported from the European Union be subject to the same legislation? And does the Commission intend to impose our farmers? What action will be taken to combat social, wage and environmental dumping of agri-food products from third countries, such as Vietnam and Cambodia?  Mr President, this is unfair competition. We must protect our farms, it is not protectionism but fairness and the health of our citizens.

name: Benoît BITEAU
text: Madam President, Commissioner, the proposal for the reform of the CAP is now being discussed by the European Parliament on the basis of a copy which was prepared by the previous mandate, and which is not in line with the expectations of this new mandate, which has already voted for a climate emergency. And this urgency is very real. The proposal for the reform of the CAP is absolutely not up to the challenge, and you are well aware of that, Commissioner. Is this "fork-to-fork" strategy a way for the Commission to address these shortcomings? Yet the CAP remains, and must remain, a powerful lever to support and finance the agroecological transition of European farmers. So how does the Commission intend to match the current cap reform proposal with the new objectives introduced by the European Green Pact? How is it that one of the most important policies in the European Union is decided before the strategy? How could it be possible to achieve the objectives of the Green Pact without mobilising the CAP, which today contains no common and clear objective of reducing pesticides, protecting biodiversity, reducing greenhouse gas emissions and achieving food sovereignty?  Citizens are counting on us, on our historic responsibility, so that we do not ration the opportunity to transform our food systems sustainably at European level. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 171, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Madam President, colleagues, I understand that you do not agree with the farm-to-consumer strategy, you do not agree that the CAP can work further, nor that we should also produce food in the European Union.  How do you imagine a European Union without agricultural products, just imported? How do you think we will have greater food safety if we import from other Member States and do not produce here? How will we ensure the lives of rural farmers as long as we have a very high percentage of citizens living in rural areas in the European Union?

name: Benoît BITEAU
text: Answer "blue card." "I didn't say I didn't agree. I ask that there be a coherence, a convergence between this fork-to-fork project and the common agricultural policy. So it's not exactly an opposition; it is simply to say that today I am surprised that a strategy is being put forward without finalizing the CAP, or rather that it affects the CAP. One way or the other.  With regard to alternatives and the risk of harm to food sovereignty, today we must converge the obligations to protect biodiversity and protect the climate, while continuing to produce a great deal. And the answer is not more pesticides and more synthetic fertilizers; it is a return to agronomy, for example.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Dear Chairman, the Common Agricultural Policy is the most expensive and least effective European policy.  In its long history, several major reforms have been attempted, but without particular success because, regardless of the specific model, the high level of state interventionism makes European agriculture expensive, inefficient and globally uncompetitive. We have a new reform period ahead of us with a focus on the circular economy, climate change and green policies. We want to make European agriculture sustainable and climate neutral in the long term, but I fear we will resort to the same solutions that have proven to be bad in the past.   New expensive public programmes and subsidies are not a sustainable solution in the long term. We need to encourage innovation in agriculture and make education programmes available to all European farmers. This is the only way to ensure the sustainable growth of this industry, boost competitiveness and prevent too high a burden on the budget.

name: Silvia MODIG
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, there is a saying in Finland which goes that the beginning of all wisdom is the recognition of facts. If we recognise the facts, we recognise that the voluntary means have not been sufficient. If they were, our fields would already be carbon sinks instead of sources of emissions. Unilateral farming, which kills biodiversity, would already have been discontinued and pesticides, which are poison for both nature and humans, would no longer be in use.  By this I do not mean that farmers should be guilty or punished. They do have the know-how, but our common agricultural policy, our agricultural subsidies and this strategy must guide them in a direction in which agricultural principles change to a more sustainable level.  Consumers are increasingly interested in ethical and ecological products. Those who can afford it are willing to pay even more for this. Therefore, subsidies must support ecological and ethical production models and labelling must help consumers to find these products in a reliable way.

name: Juan Ignacio ZOIDO ÁLVAREZ
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, let us start on the basis that a large majority of this House wants more sustainable agriculture and that it contributes to achieving the 2030 Agenda Goals. I hope that the 'farm-to-table' strategy will contribute to this, but I am concerned that some will try to make European agriculture a great tailor's drawer. I explain myself by one example: some pretend to happen with agriculture like iPhones. What started out as a phone has now become a GPS, a camera, a recorder, an internet browser, an odometer, an alarm clock, etc.; a device that serves almost everything and the thing that makes or does not make phone calls is of little interest.  Similarly, some want European agriculture to serve to preserve the environment, to combat climate change, to reduce pesticides, to reduce the use of antibiotics, to improve biodiversity, to give better information to citizens, to protect forests, to improve animal welfare, etc. But we must not forget that the main purpose of our agriculture and the common agricultural policy is to obtain quality products at reasonable prices that incentivize the great effort that our farmers make. The future of them will certainly depend a lot on this. May this farm-to-table strategy serve to help these field workers, farmers and ranchers achieve the objectives at a fair price and appropriate to their efforts.

name: Maria NOICHL
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We are supposedly talking about the farm-to-fork strategy today. And you can already see a certain nervousness here in the room, because in reality we are talking about something quite different: in reality, we are talking about – and it is precisely these conversations in all the corridors – whether the old reform proposal currently being put forward is even green-deal-capable. That is the only question. And that is why there is also such nervousness among those who always believe that they are supposed to speak for all farmers, because they have to recognise and realise that the old proposal is incompatible with the new idea of a green deal. And this nervousness is palpable, I can even understand it in some cases. But I would ask you: do not claim to be speaking for all farmers. You are talking for some of the farmers. There are also many farmers who already want to break new ground. And I am here to support these farmers.

name: Martin HLAVÁČEK
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, we have great hope for you. Farmers and food farmers have recently been wrongly dehonested and blamed. A large part of society forgets that they still produce the highest quality, safest food in the world, at affordable prices. Of course, agriculture is also one of the most regulated areas. We are constantly increasing requirements, liberalising trade, creating new rules and reducing support. Agriculture, meanwhile, is the first to feel the effects of climate change. This is also why agriculture must be part of the solution.  Unfortunately, the new Green Deal and Farm to Fork strategies do not yet count on farmers. It is a primitive proposal to make inputs more expensive, to make food more expensive, and to regulate more and more. We're approaching the limit of tolerability. It's supposed to be a farm-to-fork strategy. So why do most proposals only go to farmers and are afraid to tackle supermarkets and unfair subsidies?

name: Silvia SARDONE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in order to pursue Greta, you have invented a new programme: 'Farm to Fork'. A strategy that has as its sole pillar that of making fishermen and farmers a kind of climate guardian, with controls and jokes that make us remember a big green brother.  Among the different principles is that of having low-cost content, which obviously goes against the quality of food and instead favours industrial products. By the way, I read that you want to insert algae and insects as food, long live the quality of food! You told me in a question that you are not entirely opposed to the Nutri-Score system and that, on the contrary, you are considering including a new labelling right inside the Farm to Fork. Do not dare to put in place a new discriminatory and misleading system! We are tired of the fact that behind food health and safety you are in fact always favouring multinationals.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: – Dear President. The current system is indeed flawed and destroys one economy in one region and stimulates production in others. The dairy sector is a good example. Moreover, the market dominance of supermarkets creates threats to a wide range of consumers. This is Lithuania's largest supermarket chain Maxima last week traded poor meat and hid it. The new strategy must ensure that the consumer has access to natural, safe food produced and produced in his region. Today, food often overcomes thousands of kilometers. But does anyone ask themselves if we need it? Is it good for the environment and the climate?  Direct support to farmers in different Member States still varies from percentage to percentage, sometimes. First-class and second-class farmers still exist in Europe. And where there are still barriers created under the guise of free movement of goods and services or trade agreements opening the way for the importation of GMOs soy or products produced under dubious conditions. By facilitating the farmer's work in his country, we will ensure the viability of the regions and allow people to stay in the countryside.

name: Mazaly AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, the Spanish agricultural and livestock sector has been mobilizing for a month in the face of the crisis that plagues the sector: prices at source which do not cover production costs; abusive practices of great distribution; trade agreements with quality standards completely opposed to Europeans. In short, a lack of profitability that forces the closure of hundreds of holdings. From the European Union, the 'farm-to-table' strategy is announced in a hype and saucer and yet little or nothing is said about farmers' real concerns because we only focus on reducing plant protection products, increasing animal welfare rules, incorporating new environmental obligations.  I wonder how we are going to respond to the market crisis facing the sector in Spain and other countries of the European Union if we still do not understand that an economic sector that is not profitable can never be sustainable. On this path we will continue to move away from the reality of our field and unable to offer solutions to a sector that needs more understanding and urgent support.

name: Petros KOKKALIS
text: – Madam President, as a member of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development (AGRI), I fully support DG SANTE taking the lead in this Farm to Fork Strategy. Hippocrates said, ‘Let food be your medicine, and medicine be your food’, and here the Green Deal is equally wise in demanding a new CAP that is a climate-adaptation and a climate-mitigation strategy: a CAP that leaves no one behind and that ensures a just transition. The people of Europe deserve safe, affordable, high—quality, nutritious and sustainably-produced food, and the farmers and fishermen and women that are managing this transition deserve quality jobs in vibrant, modern rural areas. The time has come to align the CAP with the Union’s ambitions. We must have a smart, fair, sustainable CAP, with a proper budget, that would strongly support our farmers to achieve the environmental, climate, biodiversity and human well—being objectives of the Union. The Green Deal and Hippocrates also share a fundamental value: do no harm. Let’s have a new CAP.

name: Álvaro AMARO
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the Commissioner has been telling us today about some very important concerns, as you have said, and I also wanted in my political group to give him that strength. We need to avoid the depopulation of rural areas, we need to have food security and therefore we really need a higher budget for the CAP. But, Commissioner, when we are discussing this meadow-to-plate strategy, there is one thing that has made me very concerned from the outset, because it is unfair to farmers. It seems that, from one moment to the next, Europe wakes up and says: farmers are responsible for all that is wrong in our countries. This is an injustice to farmers. Because, Commissioner, you know, we all know, that you will only win a good "meadow to plate" strategy if there is meadow, because if there is no meadow and if there are only dishes, well, that strategy is dead. So that, first of all, we have to give strength to farmers, and to give strength, Commissioner, is to remember that we have to, alongside this strategy, have instruments. We know that, in strategic terms, there is nothing that wins without capable instruments. And the financial instrument is, alongside justice for European farmers, a key issue. It is for this force that we are here, to give you, to overcome these obstacles.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: – Mr President, actors in the food chain are key to offering sustainable food and promoting affordable, healthy food for all. I believe that they are key for the European Green Deal. That’s why we are looking at the Farm to Fork Strategy as a tool that can help consumers choose healthy food that is not harmful to our environment whilst at the same time reducing food waste. We know that the total global food systems are responsible for almost one third of total greenhouse gas emissions, and we need to make sure that this sector contributes to our quest in Europe for ensuring carbon neutrality by 2050. We in the S&D Group want a Farm to Fork Strategy that will help reduce emissions and that reduces food waste, pushes for more sustainable food production and creates new opportunities in the food value chain for all. We will ask for targets to reduce the use of chemical pesticides, fertilisers and antibiotics. We want a Farm to Fork strategy that guarantees consumers traceability so that they can trace healthy food that helps reduce the risk of cancer and other diseases and that reduces the risk of chemicals such as endocrine disruptors. We believe that, if we plan out our policies properly, the European Green Deal can also be a source of opportunities for food producers, including farmers and fishermen. Ultimately, they are key to offering sustainable food products that can benefit all. (The speaker agreed to take a blue—card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Róża THUN UND HOHENSTEIN
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for accepting the blue card. You mentioned the traceability of food, and I wanted to ask you what you mean by that. Traceability means distance, origin, etc. Have you also thought, and would you support, the idea that the dual quality of foods – that means that on different markets in the European Union, food has a different quality and the consumer doesn’t usually know about it – is an extremely important issue and that all consumers should get the same quality of food when it is packed in an identical way?

name: Miriam DALLI
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you for that question. The S&D has always been very clear when it comes to dual quality of foods because we believe that all EU citizens have the right to have the same quality of food wherever they are in the European Union.

name: Martin HOJSÍK
text: – Mr President, we are well aware of the massive problems that we can face if the collapse of the beehives and the loss of pollinators and other biodiversity goes really full scale. There is one very clear culprit – not the only one but one that is well known – and that’s hazardous pesticides, and their massive use in our own agriculture and agriculture around the world. Now, often many want to blame farmers, but it’s not something that is their fault; it’s basically the entire system that we’ve built. What we need to provide for them, and that’s what I expect from the Farm to Fork Strategy but also from the common agricultural policy (CAP), is that they need to be able to get the alternatives. We need to have mandatory reduction targets for pesticide use but also for the hazard. We need to have better integrated pest management available for farmers, and we need to have better access to the alternatives to hazardous pesticides on the market. I hope that the Farm to Fork Strategy will be a strategy that doesn’t only talk, but helps to deliver safe food and prosperity for farmers as well as protection for the planet.

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: – Mr President, I’d like to follow up on the topic of empowering consumers to take informed decisions, because I believe that consumer protection has always been one of the top priorities of the European Parliament. Unfortunately, the trust of customers was shaken by the unwillingness to ban dual quality of products. Luckily, we have a chance now to fix some of these issues within the Farm to Fork Strategy. A recent study done by the Joint Research Centre showed that information about product quality is very important to European citizens. We need to strengthen the right for information to ease consumer’s decisions. The key is the labelling on the front of packs informing, for example, about the origin of the product. My second point is about health aspects. Tests prove that similar products are sold with different sweeteners or different amount of fat in some Member States. Lower healthiness of products should not be accepted, and it is a topic that the Commission should address in this strategy.

name: Nicola PROCACCINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the strategy from farm to table is widely shared by both farmers and consumers, especially in my nation, Italy. On the other hand, it is not an economically neutral strategy. The right choice of sustainable agriculture increases the cost of production and consequently the purchase price of products.  I am thinking in particular of organic farming and the fight against intensive farming. That is why, without adequate economic support, without a CAP that will protection small and medium-sized farmers over large farms, we are only in danger of doing environmental demagoguery and nothing more.  Food labelling will also be decisive. Properly informing consumers about the territorial origins and nutritional properties of food cannot be considered an optional but a duty on the part of the European Union. Good job, Commissioner.

name: Manuel BOMPARD
text: Mr President, a European food policy is essential to ensure everyone has access to healthy and quality food. This policy should include the implementation of a pesticide exit plan and the immediate ban on the most dangerous, such as glyphosate; support for organic farming, which begins with the rejection of the budget cut for the second pillar of the CAP; Reducing the consumption of meat proteins by the end of intensive farming; and increased aid to plant crops for human consumption. But these changes will not happen without farmers who today cannot afford to live with dignity. Because a handful of farms, owners of huge areas, actually monopolize a large part of the European funds. To better distribute these funds, we propose to take into account the number of assets rather than the surface and to introduce a real cap on aid. We are fighting to increase aid to small farms by raising the redistributive payment to at least 30% of the budget, as proposed by the Committee of the Regions. Only in this way can we enable our farmers to live well and thus meet the challenge of ecological agriculture of tomorrow.

name: Marlene MORTLER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. Commissioner, we would have liked to have talked to your colleague Mr Timmermans today and not about him, because a farm-to-fork strategy without us agricultural policy farmers is a no-go. It is certainly not right to talk about our farmers as if they were all criminals. They will take to the streets again if they do not understand your laws, because they do not work and operate on a whim or according to the motto 'a lot of fertilizer helps a lot', but according to the requirements of the EU and the Member States. If Timmermans now wants to drastically reduce pesticides and improve the quality of food – okay, but we don't start from scratch. It is common practice to reduce and optimize the use of fertilizers and pesticides. The latest research results from the official food monitoring confirm that food from Europe is by far the safest in the world. So don't play with the fire of fake news! Look for good solutions and not for culprits! Our farmers are open and ready for innovative ideas. But if the market, the consumer, does not pay and reward additional requirements, restrictions and bans, then it must pay the timmermans' house. We can do without much in life, but not our daily bread. That is why we need and value our farmers in Europe. Agriculture and forestry is the only industry that produces oxygen and binds carbon dioxide, which means that the climate is good. I call on Mr Timmermans to ensure a good political climate and not to leave our farmers in the rain. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the "blue card" procedure under Rule 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Martin HÄUSLING
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mrs Mortler, I would like to thank Mrs Mortler for her work You know that the "Biofach" is taking place in Nuremberg. There are farmers who can produce bread without pesticides. They are pretending to always use pesticides and fertilisers. The question arises: would you be prepared to further promote this sector? After all, you have had a referendum in Bavaria which clearly says: we must come down from the quantities. They are just pretending that everything is fine. Do you see it that way, or do we need to change something?

name: Marlene MORTLER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr President, I would like to thank my colleague for his work They are insinuating to me here things that I have not said. We are always in the process of reducing pesticides and fertilizers and optimizing the whole thing. Do not pretend that there is no use of fertilizer and pesticides in organic farming. That is what there is. By the way, I'm at the "Biofach" tomorrow. So I'm not hiding, I'm talking to everyone. And the question - now I've lost the thread, that happens. But the question that I would like to pass on to you, namely to Mrs Wiener, is this: ask why she still receives eu support for her business when she is ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on his excellent Food is life, and it is vital that we in Europe, and for the part of our planet, change our agriculture as soon as possible so that it becomes climate-sustainable and environmentally sustainable.  The "farm-to-table" strategy for sustainable food is an important component of the green deal. It is because we are using it now. Food production accounts for one third of climate emissions. It is also the contributing factor when it comes to many of the species that we see dying out. Not least bees are very hard hit. It is important for our food production that we deal with this. There are opportunities for improvement, and we must take that on board now. Our aim must be sustainable agriculture. The EU's regulations and tax resources should be used to reverse the trend, not the other way around. It is also a question of reducing greenhouse gases, but it is also a question of strengthening biodiversity, removing endocrine disruptors and combating antibiotic resistance. The "from farm to fork" strategy means healthy food that protects the environment!

name: Asger CHRISTENSEN
text: Mr President! I myself am a farmer and very concerned with the 'farm to fork' strategy. Food and eating is very important to us humans. Our food must meet many things: they must be healthy, they must be nutritious, they must be produced sustainably, and they must be climate-friendly.  Can the Commission tell me whether the strategy will include measures that will make it easier for our consumers to see how our food is produced, whether it is climate friendly and whether animal welfare and health are intact? I would also like to ask the Commission how it intends to take account of all agriculture in the European Union, both large and small. I think it is absolutely crucial that we focus on the fact that all farms in the European Union should be sustainable and not focus on size. It is essential that all farmers are part of this process.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Mr President, the Farm to Fork Strategy is a massive opportunity to take a genuinely holistic approach to dealing with the crises of biodiversity, climate change, health, inequality, farming and animal welfare. The Strategy leaked last month does contain a welcome reference to supporting primary producers in the transition. However, there is zero reference to a sustainable price for the primary producer. Small—scale family farms are the main providers of diverse and nutritious food for 70% of the world’s population. However, these producers are increasingly threatened by the globalised industrial food system, which includes greedy processors and corporate supermarkets. In Ireland, there has been a six—fold increase in the number of feedlots in the country over the last ten years. In the 1970’s, the majority of Irish farms were less than 20 hectares. Today they are over 32, as the big gobble up the small. During the same period, Ireland has lost 140 000 family farms due to government policy and EU policy. The Strategy is an opportunity to reverse the intensive industrialised approach to food production.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – Mr President! European farmers already produce the highest quality and safest food today, and production is also environmentally and animal-friendly.  The Green Deal is only possible with cooperation with farmers. The peasants will do it, not anyone else. It is therefore essential that we have on the web these strategies, from the Green Agreement to the fork-to-fork strategy, the common agricultural policy, measures that will stimulate farmers, not ban them. We must do everything to make agriculture interesting to young people, not to make people afraid of farming. We must support family farms, enable the reduction of the use of pesticides and fertilisers by means of a focus on agriculture, to stimulate people, environmentally and animal-friendly agriculture. We must support short chains that allow fair earnings for food producers and a competitive price for the consumer, prevent large traders from hindering farmers and reduce the proportion of food wasted. We will achieve this goal through positive measures, not by banning and with fear.

name: Günther SIDL
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. I expect the farm-to-fork strategy to provide holistic access to sustainable food production. These include farmers, consumers, the processing industry, food chains, the issue of food safety, animal welfare, environmental protection, mandatory climate protection measures including the preservation of biodiversity and much more along the entire value chain. The aim is to significantly reduce the use of pesticides, fertilisers and antibiotics in the future. It is about a circular economy and about reducing food waste as well. And we need different access to trade agreements and to imports of genetic engineering into Europe. The Commission has a crucial political role to play here. It is about credibility in all policy areas.

name: Elsi KATAINEN
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, a comprehensive review of the food system is very much needed, both for the environment and for the producer. The farm-to-table strategy gives a really good opportunity to assess this whole long food chain, but this must not mean just limiting the ups. The strategy must therefore look beyond the farmer and the farm level: storage, handling, packaging, distribution and food waste. They all affect outside the premises, but are reflected both in the space level and also in the environment.  The Unfair Trade Practices Directive was hopefully just the beginning. It must be understood that only a profitable farm can produce food and be good, including for the climate. That is why this strategy must provide an even more solid basis for the whole food chain to be sustainable, including in terms of the profitability of farms and the standard of living of the producer.  As a farmer myself, I can be satisfied. We've just had a generational change. That is what we must strive for, Commissioner: that young Europeans can continue this valuable profession.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: I would just like to make one announcement: I would like to conclude the nominations for the spontaneous speeches at this moment. We have enough nominations. I would just like to point out that there are also people on the list who have spoken in the main debate, and I do not take them. And those who cast a "blue card" during the main debate cannot get there either. These are three people who have registered but have already taken part in the debate.

name: Christine SCHNEIDER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has We will only be able to achieve the ambitious objectives of the farm-to-fork strategy with agriculture and not against it. Previous speakers have already stressed the importance of involving agriculture. The core task of our farms is the production of healthy food, and our task is to set the appropriate framework conditions. It is of the utmost importance to me that the Commission, within the framework of the farm-to-fork strategy, ensures the competitiveness of our eu businesses in relation to the international market. Additional requirements, such as the reduction of plant protection products, will only be feasible if the Commission and the European Parliament are open to the authorisation and use of new technologies. We also need fair remuneration for agricultural products and recognition of the performance of our farmers for society. The consumer plays a key role in this. Only if the consumer is able to make informed decisions when choosing food will we achieve this objective, and that is why we also need a European-coordinated food labelling system.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, you are well aware that most of this House are committed to the Sustainable Development Goals and, of course, to our commitments to the Paris Summit. Obviously, for both my group and most of this House, those are our objectives. But I do not think that two major programmes, the farm-to-table strategy or the Green Pact, which are great programmes and generate high expectations, that agriculture causes difficulties and that major changes must be made to it, without recognizing what has already been done. That is, we cannot focus only on the elimination of phytosanitary products. It is an important element, but farmers must be made easier to find innovation, biological control and other elements. They have to be given an alternative to this situation. Without complicity and without commitment to agriculture it is impossible for this programme, that this strategy will succeed. So, with everyone's commitment, let's move it forward. Not with a back to the farmers.

name: Atidzhe ALIEVA-VELI
text: – Mr President, Honourable Commissioner, honourable Members, the European Union has the ambition to set the global guidelines for sustainable agriculture. However, I believe that a sustainable food system can only be achieved through a holistic, balanced, fair and coordinated approach. In order for the transition and strategy to be ambitious and genuinely achievable, they need to be secured with the necessary financial resources and a simplified regulatory framework. In this regard, I appeal to the Commission to ensure synergies between the different funding lines and the different strategies concerning agriculture, and to ensure strong mutual complementarity of policies in different areas. There is no doubt that farmers will play a central role in achieving the objectives of the strategy, and they must be heard, understood, supported and encouraged, and not subject to unfair accusations. Only if all stakeholders are involved in this process can we achieve a balanced approach, environment and fair income for farmers.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, this is not easy for you, believe me, farmers are watching this debate because they know that the strategy is about them, and that strategy must be for them. They expect us to support them.  They know that the effects of climate change are primarily on them. They know that these are not the effects of the Green Deal, but that they are the effects of climate change. If it is not freezing in the Czech Republic today, it means that diseases and pests are multiplying and a lower harvest can be expected. This is not the impact of the Green Deal, but it is the impact of climate change that we must combat, but we must support our farmers in this. They also bear the costs and risks of cheaper imports from third countries. Then there is also the challenge of the food chains, as my colleague mentioned here, because most people shop in retail chains and they have much more power.  Please, I have a question for you: How do you work to better position farmers vis-à-vis food chains? That bothers us a lot. We must support active farmers who live in the countryside, who take care of land, forests and preserve biodiversity. Please support active farmers.

name: Alessandra MORETTI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the food chain is responsible for between 21 % and 37 % of total CO2 emissions. Such a system is no longer sustainable, not least in the light of the challenge we face: producing more using fewer resources and guaranteeing healthy and quality food for all.  Let us not underestimate the political moment we are experiencing. The citizens are on our side and demanding transparency and security, but legislation alone is not enough. We need a radical change in the whole system and our way of life. The holistic approach is crucial. We need greater synergy between the different policies, health and agriculture in the first place, which must complement and not clash. Finally, it is clear to everyone that consumers are aware of the value of food, from the point of view of healthiness and the processes that contribute to bringing it to our tables. That is why we need to devise a uniform package labelling system, which informs the consumer without affecting him and which is based on sound scientific justifications.

name: Benoît LUTGEN
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to start by saying that I have great confidence in European agricultural production and that we can be generally proud of all that is produced here. After all I have heard this morning, it is important to be able to say it again and to say thank you to our farming friends. The fork-fork strategy, for me, is perhaps a reconciliation between consumers and farmers. Three things seem essential to me. First, that there be active participation in this strategy from the agricultural world, whether it is part of this strategy, as well as to consumers. Second, that there be new guarantees in financing and investment to enable this transition. Farmers do not have to be the variable for adjusting European budgets, nor the adjustment value in the Green Pact; they must be supported in their investments and in the transition. And thirdly, the essential element is protection: consumer protection, protection of farmers, protection of the environment. It can only be done if controls are tightened and equivalence is introduced for products imported into our territory, to put an end to certain injustices and misunderstandings on the part of consumers. I wish you good luck in this strategy.

name: Mohammed CHAHIM
text: Mr President, we must now take the cow by the horns. A "Farm to Fork" Strategy – or a farmer-to-plate strategy – without reform of our agricultural policy, is like the horse behind the cart. The farmers, who work hard every day to make a fair product for us, who take good care of their animals and handle their land and water use responsibly, benefit little from this policy.  The only common common thing about this policy is that in almost every Member State 80% of the subsidy goes to the 20 richest. If we make this a top 100 or a top 200, it will not have one real farmer on it, but mainly multinationals and landowners, companies that often generate millions, sometimes billions of turnover.  Of course, we are pleased that there will be a farmer-to-council strategy, but without reform of agricultural policy, we will abandon farmers who are good with their land and water use and continue to fatten polluting multinationals and wealthy landowners.

name: Jarosław KALINOWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. New challenges and responsibilities for farmers and agriculture in the European Union, but also much greater burdens related to the European Green Deal. However, the agricultural budget is unfortunately proposed to be reduced. If that's the case, it just won't work out. In addition, direct payments must finally go to real farmers. Pathology is a situation where the majority of beneficiaries are not farmers, but owners of agricultural land. Commissioner, please refer to the european Commission's planned new tax on animal products: meat and dairy products. This would reduce consumption and thus reduce greenhouse gas emissions. This is of great concern to producers as well as consumers. If this were to be a pillar of this strategy, it would result in a deterioration in the incomes of food producers in the European Union and the competitiveness of European agriculture.

name: Carmen AVRAM
text: – Mr President, the Green Deal is shaping up to be the biggest revolution since industrialisation, and perhaps the hardest task has been placed on farmers' shoulders. Under unclear but certainly much tougher conditions, he will have to feed hundreds of millions of people healthy and sustainably.  It's just that the European farmer is in danger, and with him our revolution. For today agriculture seems to many a chore, it is too heavy, too expensive, too exposed to factors impossible to control, too little rewarded. So many have already abandoned it and many are preparing to do so. Who are we putting these people in place, where do we get the generation of farmers to get involved in the Farm to Fork strategy that will make the Green Deal a success goal?  The European Commission must consider that, in parallel with the ambitious strategies already announced, it will start another one, an urgent programme to encourage and prepare young people to return to the countryside and take on the mission of carrying out the revolution that we are talking about today.

name: Anne SANDER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the fork-to-fork strategy has the potential to bring a great deal to our agri-food sector as well as to the end consumer, but to succeed we will have to be consistent and realistic. Consistency, because the climate issue requires a substantial budget, to the extent of the challenge we face. We cannot accept the proposed budget cuts and ask our farmers to do more with less. We also need to perfect the link between the current CAP reform and the Green Pact.  Realism, because we absolutely have to base our decisions on science, not on ideology.
