Let us not lead our sectors into technical impasses and deprive them of innovative technologies, while the world and our competitors are making great strides.  Finally, let us remember that our farmers are the solution, that they will have to be at the heart of our strategy, and that we will also have to meet the vital imperatives of economic viability and competitiveness.

name: Antonius MANDERS
text: Mr President, I have a point of order. You have just indicated that people who have drawn a blue card are not eligible for "catch the eye". I believe that this should be included in the Rules of Procedure. Otherwise, I object to this, because if you had said so at the beginning of the debate, I would not have drawn the blue card. So I think I am entitled to the catch-the-eye procedure.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: It does not have to be in the Rules of Procedure, mr. because the Rules of Procedure also state that the President decides how many 'blue cards' and which ones we can accept. When I took over the Presidency, I said what I was doing because I have too many requests to speak; and because I have too many speeches, I had to make a classification of how I deal with it. Spontaneous speeches

name: Traian BĂSESCU
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, agriculture is one of Europe's vital economic activities, but also in Romania.  Unfortunately, competition on the European market between farmers is deeply distorted by the level of subsidies granted. For example, in Romania, per hectare, the subsidy is 190 euros, in France, 420 euros. Of course, I am not for reducing the subsidy in France, but I am also advocateing for increasing the subsidy for Romanian farmers. The same phenomenon happens in the breeding of animals. Industry companies have come to import raw materials from the old countries of the European Union, and raw materials are not sold in Romania because it is more expensive than that of the other Member States.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Mr President, we have had a very interesting debate here today on the 'farm to paper' strategy. It is absolutely necessary that we carry it.  I am a farmer's daughter and I have to be honest when we also have to think about the fact that we should not always blame farmers for everything in this debate. Of course, farmers must cooperate with the Green Deal and the measures. But let us be honest: in recent years – hold on to you – a thousand companies have disappeared every day in the European Union. A thousand farmers a day who disappear in the European Union. It hurts me. Four million over the last few years. We have a beautiful television programme in Flanders: "Boer zkt Vrouw". I fear that we will soon have to make a programme 'Europe zkt Boer'. That is why I am asking you, Commissioner, to bet on agriculture. Let agriculture survive. What do we have to do for that? We need to strengthen the position of farmers in the chain, open new markets, improve prices, support young farmers, and above all: solve the Russia boycott.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Mr President, it is good that the Commission has highlighted this farm-to-table strategy. Hopefully, it will also be a broadly food policy sustainable food programme that tackles the entire production cycle, from primary production to food waste, with the aim of making the best possible choices from an environmental point of view, from the producer's point of view and from the point of view of human health, which, as we know, also generates a fair income for producers in developing countries and in finland, decent treatment of animals, healthy food and reduces environmental pollution and helps to solve climate change. We know that this is possible. Our current agricultural policy – the common agricultural policy and its financing – is not just paying off. Do you also intend to correct the CAP proposal accordingly so that it supports the sustainable food policy?

name: Sandra PEREIRA
text: – Mr President, I come from the rural world where, unfortunately, we are well known about the impact that the CAP has had on our lands, on our people and on our lives. That's why we're concerned about this "meadow-to-plate" strategy. How do you think about ensuring a fair income for producers to produce quality food or avoid leaving the rural world without facing the foundations of the current Common Agricultural Policy?  How will you ensure safe and available food to all with your neoliberal guidelines that only promote competitiveness and open up the primary sectors to global competition, which feed unsustainable models of intensive production and agro-business and that call into question biodiversity and the planet's own limits? Food sovereignty, the promotion of short distribution circuits, the defense of small and medium-sized agriculture, family farming and the rural world should be parts of the path that goes "from meadow to plate", and this is not compatible with the interests that you represent and serve.

name: Salvatore DE MEO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, this is a delicate moment. Farmers – I would like to make this clear – are living, living economies, they are passion, sacrifice, real work, they represent a know-how that has been handed down over generations and regenerates. From here I often hear about challenges, but I would like to remind you that farmers accept a challenge every day, fight and are ready to take on other challenges, but we must make them protagonists, we cannot blame them. I would like to make it clear that there is quality agriculture here, an agriculture that does not mean being at odds with the Green Deal. We are well aware that the Common Agricultural Policy has been a feature of the European Union's integrative process, and that is why it is a reality in relation to so many other challenges which are worthy but which must be tested. We have a duty with this initiative to push on seasonality, territoriality, correct information that cannot be summarized in a traffic light and an algorithm, because behind each product there is a history and an identity of a territory.

name: Milan UHRÍK
text: – Mr President, colleagues, we tried to implement this farm-to-table strategy already at the level of regional self-government in Slovakia, and we also wanted to buy Slovak regional food in schools, but we came across European Union legislation. Because when we launched the tendering procedure, we could not put a condition on the geographical origin of the food, and so, legally, those public procurements were won by various importers of cheaper foreign food. It is no wonder that foreign food was cheaper, because those European Union subsidies are indeed unfairly set up. In the order of order of Slovakia, a farmer receives around EUR 200 per hectare, in Austria 250, in Germany 300, in Italy even 400, I am talking about the first pillar of the CAP. Not to mention that 80% of these subsidies go to 20% of the largest farms, so there is no support for small, local farmers, and at the end of the day it is not a farm-to-table strategy, but from truck to warehouse, so this needs to change.

name: Tudor CIUHODARU
text: – Mr President, this strategy must ensure three clear things.  Firstly, support for farmers, and here I am talking about subsidies, tax facilities and advice. Secondly, consumer support and we all want safe products, properly labelled and by the same standard. And at the same time, thirdly, environmental support.  But this strategy must be matched by concrete and binding measures. And that is why I am asking you today, Commissioner, because I come from Romania, the same subsidies for Romanian farmers, similar to those which are in France, Austria or Germany. On the other hand, the same food standards, the same type of food to be marketed throughout Europe, because we all meet the double standard, and especially in my country, Romania.  And thirdly, the initiation of a advisory programme to help farmers across Europe to access the necessary funds for organic farming.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, it isn’t that often that I agree with my colleague Mr Wallace, but I agree with him completely in the distinction he makes between the factory feedlots and the small farms in the West of Ireland and, indeed, probably in rural Europe as well. Those small family farms are genuine grass-based farms, producing nutritious food in the best possible environmental ways, and they are the people who will take care of the environment for us. I think that the feedlots are trading on the back of this. There’s no distinction made between their food and the food that’s produced by the genuine farmers. They’re getting huge CAP payments which they neither need nor deserve. I think there’s an opportunity now, under the next CAP and also under Mr Timmermans’ Farm to Fork Strategy, to make that distinction so that those who are genuinely needful of support will get it, and especially those who are actually genuinely producing grass-based food, not factory lots.

name: Janusz WOJCIECHOWSKI
text: Member. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Thank you very much for all your statements. I am sorry that I will not apply to each of them, because the time That I am entitled to does not allow this, but it was really a very interesting and necessary debate and it is good that it took place right now. I therefore thank Mr Lins and the Committee on Agriculture once again for this initiative. We do not yet have a field-to-table strategy, we are working on this strategy. There are some directions in which it will go, because that is what the Green Deal has already decided, but we still have time to introduce many of your demands, including those that have fallen in this House. I will use this debate – by participating in the work on the strategy, in so far as it concerns my responsibilities, I will want to use as many of your suggestions as possible in this work. I would just like to remind you that the Commissioner for Health, Mrs Kyriakides, is responsible. I am, of course, working on this agricultural part and we have mainly talked about it today, because farmers are the main ones responsible for the future implementation of the strategy. And I fully agree with these statements, and I have also said this myself, that this must be done with farmers, not against farmers, that we must use incentives. That is why I have talked so much about the budget that, in order, for example, to encourage farmers to have programmes to reduce the use of plant protection products, fertilisers, better water management, other environmental measures, we need to have the resources to do so. They must be sufficient in the first pillar, because they will be eco-programmes, there must be measures in the second pillar of action, different environmental actions. That is why this budget is so important. You have raised the issue of order here, and I, too, would prefer to be in a situation where we have adopted strategies and now we are adapting the common agricultural policy to these strategies. We are in a different situation, these assumptions of the common agricultural policy were developed as recently as 2018. President von der Leyen's committee does not propose a new agricultural policy, because we simply do not have time for this. We want to bring the work on the common agricultural policy to an end as soon as possible by adapting it, and that will be our joint work, cooperation between the Commission, Parliament and the Council, so that these rules of the common agricultural policy are applied to the strategies that we will adopt. The strategy and the measures it provides are an opportunity, above all, for smaller and medium-sized farms, those farms that are disappearing so quickly, which we are losing so quickly. And there is room in Europe for different types of farms – for larger, more intensive, and for smaller, more extensive economies. They are particularly – these smaller farms – prepared for these environmental challenges, it will be easier for them to meet these conditions. The idea is that these big farms don't cause these little ones to disappear, there has to be a balance. This sustainability must also be the case with regard to the relationship between the different types of farms in European agriculture. Organic farming has a great opportunity. As part of this strategy, we will do everything we can to develop organic farms, but not only to increase the area of these farms, but to promote consumption, to reach consumers, to show the value of this food. Moreover, European food in general, and this is our success, the success of European agriculture, is of the highest quality in the world, meets the highest standards and this is an asset when it comes to world markets. We must, of course, protect our producers. Many of your voices here have been about protecting our farmers' imports. Yes, we should require the same standards that are required of us. There are also some restrictions from the World Trade Organisation and the rules that apply there. Strategic plans will be key documents on which we will work. I can give you a fair suing that, when assessing the strategic plans put forward by the Member States, I will do everything to ensure that there is as little red tape as possible, that bureaucracy does not hinder the development of agriculture, and that it does not hinder the lives of farmers, because this sometimes happens. I confirm that such situations are the case. Once again, thank you very much for an interesting, very interesting discussion. I think that not only we in this House, but also our farmers, have obtained a certain assessment of the situation in which we are going. I assure you once again that the European Commission will do everything to ensure that this policy, these strategies, and both the Green Deal and the field-to-table strategy, are implemented with farmers, for their benefit and for the good future of agriculture in Europe.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Asim ADEMOV
text: in writing. – The farm-to-table strategy adds to farmers' concerns that they are bearing the brunt of the environmental transition. Farmers are part of the solution, not the problem of climate change. However, they are only one unit of the entire agri-food system, along with processors, traders, consumers. As part of this system, we are all jointly and severally responsible for the environmental impact. There needs to be a change in our thinking as consumers. Are we prepared to pay a higher price for food produced in an environmentally friendly and sustainable way? Achieving the objectives of the Green Pact on zero pollution and reduced use of chemical pesticides depends on our joint work with farmers. If we want results, we need to work together with the farmers, not against them. They should be included in the strategy debate as soon as possible. Instead of constantly ingesting new obligations and ever-higher requirements, we need to think about how to stimulate them in order to implement environmental practices on our farms. New instruments are needed to finance the transition, not to do so at the expense of the CAP budget. We must not delay the adoption of the new CAP because of the Green Pact, because farmers need certainty and predictability.

name: Billy KELLEHER
text: in writing. – Irish farmers rely on CAP funding for up to 56% of family farm income (Teagasc National Farm Survey 2017). If 40% of CAP is to be dedicated to climate action then the overall budget must be increased to ensure adequate and essential funding is still provided to small, family farms. Additionally, outdated farm vehicles contribute more to greenhouse gases and pollution, therefore the CAP should provide financial aid to farms looking to update their machinery to more environmentally friendly models, which will lessen their carbon footprint. Farmers are the custodians of the land. It is in their interests for that land to be healthy and usable. They can and want to be our biggest allies in helping protect the planet, but we must bring them with us, and not alienate them. The Mercosur deal is not good for farmers or for the environment. Europe does not need to import beef from South America. The production and transportation of such beef would be detrimental to meeting our carbon reduction targets. We already have a supply of quality beef from Member States, including Ireland, and the deal makes no sense in terms of the commitments under the European Green Deal to implement it.

name: Riho TERRAS
text: Writing. – "From field to cheek" or "Farm to Fork" is a worthy initiative. However, at this point, I would like to remind you that other factors are also at stake in guaranteeing quality agricultural production. In order for agriculture to be healthy and sustainable, it is often necessary to provide financial support to the sector. However, the current system of European Union subsidies is sowing injustice, as our subsidies in Estonia are much smaller than those in Western and southern Europe. In addition, much higher subsidies in the rest of Europe will harm the competitiveness of our farmers. That is why I am of the opinion that the European Union's agricultural subsidies must either be equalised or abolished altogether. I am absolutely not satisfied with the 'explanation' that the rest of Europe is receiving higher subsidies, as their rates of support were once set out in the ancient criteria before our accession to the European Union. Given that, unlike southern Europe, our latitudes cannot receive two or three catches per year, our subsidies should be at least the same as in Western and Southern Europe.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on six motions for resolutions on Guinea, in particular on violence against protesters (2020/2551 (RSP)).

name: Pierrette HERZBERGER-FOFANA
text: Author. Mr President, the Republic of Guinea is going through a difficult period, marked by increased violence that threatens democratic stability. Political power and sovereignty are and must remain in the hands of the people. The will of the people must be respected and reflected in state institutions. Since last year, when a referendum was announced to amend the constitution, the political opposition and civil society have challenged this draft and the political climate has turned violent. During the demonstrations, abuses from all sides took place. Police violence has resulted in numerous casualties, which has caused great emotion and even concern in the international community, for example when the police used a woman as a shield to protect themselves from the stone-throwing of protesters. The whole world was shocked by this upsurge in violence. The crucial question that can be asked is: where does this violence come from, what causes it? We encourage Guinea to engage in dialogue in order to find appropriate answers to this crucial question and to establish other participatory processes that allow for peaceful and inclusive consideration of different political ideas. We urge Guinea to do everything possible to put an end to this deleterious situation. It is unacceptable for protesters to be beaten, tear gas canistered and other abused. We deplore the deaths of all those who lost their lives in these demonstrations. The Guinean government has emphasized Guinea's sovereignty and has said that no other state or foreign political actor will be able to make decisions for the country. Yet within the country, we should not exclude or threaten population groups that do not support the political line chosen by the government of the day. It is important for the European Union to develop our partnership with Africa, to nuance and multiply our relations with diverse actors, to support the rule of law, human rights and the so-called democratic, inclusive process, at home and among our partners in Africa.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Author. Mr President, Alpha Condé must face the obvious: his plan for a third term brings seeds of instability for Guinea, but also for the region.  Opposition and civil society protests against the referendum led to a violent crackdown by Guinean security forces, who literally opened fire on unarmed protesters. The violence highlights the inability of the security forces to respond adequately to crisis situations in the country for years. Since October 2019, at least 28 civilians have been killed in the protests. If we go back to 2015, more than 70 protesters lost their lives. In this country, the opposition is gagged, freedom of speech is suppressed and the population is afraid.  We condemn this violence and urge the Guinean government to improve the management of demonstrations in order to create a safe environment for protesters and, on the other hand, we call for an investigation into the perpetrators of violence and murder. In addition, we call for the immediate release of those who have been imprisoned for exercising their fundamental right to protest.  We regret President Condé's decision on the constitution and his third term, which could undermine the rule of law and democracy. Alpha Condé, once a defender of democracy and alternation, should remember where he came from. Finally, we call on the President to work with Cedeao to find a democratic solution to this political crisis, with human rights as its central pillar. We also call on the External Action Service to engage with Guinea in dialogue and mediation to deal with the violence related to these elections.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Author. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I think it is necessary to put pressure, pressure from the European Union, but not requests, not just to pay attention, but even to make our humanitarian and economic aid dependent, especially, on that country on whether the basic standards are respected there. And the President of Guinea is worth recalling the European experience – those prime ministers on our continent who lost power as a result of the referendum they held: Prime Minister Matteo Renzi in Italy – constitutional referendum, Prime Minister Cameron – referendum on Brexit. All these prime ministers have ceased to be prime ministers because they have held referendums like this. I think this could be an argument for the President of Guinea.

name: Idoia VILLANUEVA RUIZ
text: Author. – Madam President, protesting is not a crime, it is a human right; it is a political right; is the legitimate response of the peoples to take charge of their destiny. Something that shouldn't be necessary to remember. However, we are experiencing a widespread setback in civil and political rights in the world—the crackdown on protest—as I saw firsthand in Chile. But it's also happening in Europe, the Middle East or Asia. Today we are talking about Guinea , which is in mass demonstrations calling for the constitutional limit of two presidential mandates not to be exceeded. We join in the solidarity of people on the streets, the demands of African human rights agencies and the United Nations. We want the right of demonstration to be respected, human rights violations to be stopped and protesters, journalists and human rights defenders released. But today too we want to denounce the double standard of the European Union, which claims to defend human rights, but continues to sell weapons material in cases such as guinea; that does not act to ensure that European multinationals respect human rights; which instrumentalizes development aid for border control and does not invoke human rights clauses in its own Treaties, even now in the Cotonou Agreement.

name: David LEGA
text: author. – Madam President, those who need to change the constitution to stay in power should probably consider a change of career path. That obviously goes for people like Vladimir Putin, but it certainly goes for Alpha Condé as well. And that, my friends, is not the only thing that those two presidents have in common. On top of their shared flair for gunning down citizens voicing their concerns, imprisoning journalists reporting their stories, and persecuting opposition leaders exercising their democratic rights, Condé and Putin are in the mining business together. As the holder of the world’s largest reserves of bauxite, from which aluminium is created, Guinea has something that Russia wants. Russian firm Rusal, the largest producer of aluminium outside of China, gets 27% of its bauxite from Guinea, and that makes Guinea the single most important source of the company’s total bauxite production. So it’s not much of a surprise, then, that Russia’s former ambassador to Guinea openly backed Mr Condé’s unconstitutional attempts to stay in office. Since 2002, 11 African leaders have taken doubtful measures to prolong their time in office. Alpha Condé is about to become number 12 on that not-so-very-flattering list. One needs to know when it’s time to let go and to step down, because the people of Guinea deserve their democracy embedded in their constitution that they have fought so long and hard for. The people of Guinea deserve better.

name: Jan-Christoph OETJEN
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which President Alpha Condé was once hopeful for a democratic future in the Republic of Guinea. Today, at the end of his second term, parliamentary elections are being postponed and a constitutional amendment is being sought, and he is expected to seek a third mandate. Worse still, demonstrations are being crushed; Demonstrations that arise because this amendment to the Constitution has been proposed, and these are people who say: we do not agree with this, we want democratic elections to take place, as our Constitution provides for in our country. But the government is crushing these demonstrations, arresting opponents and, ladies and gentlemen, we cannot allow this to happen, and we condemn this in the strongest possible terms at this point. We expect the government to respect human and civil rights; above all, however, that opponents will be released immediately if they have been arrested for political reasons, and we expect the right to demonstrate to be respected so that people can express their opinions. The best thing would be for these people to finally be able to express their opinion in a general election, because democratic elections are what the people of the Republic of Guinea now deserve, and this should be done urgently in the near future. There must be no further postponement, the project of amending the constitution must be withdrawn. Alpha Condé cannot have a third term, but the people of Guinea must now have the floor.

name: Seán KELLY
text: thar ceann an Ghrúpa PPE. – A Uachtaráin, nuair a toghadh an tUachtarán Alpha Condé in 2010, ceapadh go raibh ré nua órga dhaonlathach i ndán don Ghuine. Ach, cosúil le a lán daoine, nuair a chuaigh sé i gcumhacht, bhí ardmheas aige ar an gcumhacht agus theastaigh uaidh an chumhacht a choimeád dó féin. Tháinig sé anuas go trom ar dhaoine a bhí ag déanamh agóide agus ar lucht an fhreasúra.  Anois feicimid go bhfuil sé ag iarraidh an bunreacht a athrú i dtreo is gur féidir leis fanacht i gcumhacht ar feadh tréimhse níos faide. Ní nach ionadh go raibh mórshiúlta agóide ann. Ach cad a tharla? Thángadar anuas go trom orthu arís. Lámhachadh daoine agus mar sin de.  Dá bhrí sin, is ceart agus is cóir go bpléifimis an cás seo inniu faoin nGuine agus go gcuirfimis gach brú is féidir ar an Uachtarán Alpha Condé chun an bunreacht a leanúint, ionas go mbeidh toghcháin shaora acu anois.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, undemocratic winds are blowing in Guinea-Conakry, where Alpha Condé, who has presided over the country for ten years, is preparing to submit to a referendum a constitutional amendment to his measure to allow a third term to be applied for. The intention to refer to the Constitution, which was joined in the marking of legislative elections for the same date, generated, of course, a wave of protests in the country, and the authorities reacted with arbitrary arrests and violent assaults, which caused hundreds of injuries and more than two dozen dead. The action of opposition parties and civil society organisations has been conditioned and the limits on freedom of expression and information have been aggravated. The right of demonstration was heavily ensnated by the police forces. In this context, the European Union and regional partners, such as ECOWAS, must be vigilant and ask for additional responsibilities and clarification stemming from the escalation of state violence in the country, insisting to the authorities on the importance of holding fair and free legislative elections. To this end, the independence and robustness of the National Election Commission must be ensured and the participation of the various political parties in the democratic exercise must be ensured. Stability in Guinea-Conakry, as in neighbouring countries, is essential. It is not acceptable for policy makers, driven by the desire for perpetuation in power, to record the difficult life situations faced by their populations. The situation requires all our attention and vigilance, as well as the international community, at a sensitive time for the future of Guinea-Conakry.

name: Lars Patrick BERG
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I am a little surprised that the Republic of Guinea is the subject of this emergency meeting. We are all aware of the demonstrations and violence in the country, but there are a lot of conjectures and assumptions in this resolution. Even the Advice that the secretariat of the DROI Committee has sought from Amnesty International is cautious in its assertions, and indeed it also refers to violent demonstrations against the government. Then we should not be surprised if there are also violent backlashes by the security forces.  President Condé was the first democratically elected President of the Republic of Guinea, and he has stated that he wants to reform the Constitution because it is a remnant of the colonial era. This is not a dictatorship, it is offering a referendum on this issue, elections are also planned which will give the electorate the opportunity to decide for themselves the future of the Republic of Guinea. One of the problems is that some opposition parties are threatening not only an electoral boycott, but also not holding the elections at all.  Instead of the megaphone diplomacy that these urgent debates are, perhaps we can work constructively with the authorities. The people of the Republic of Guinea have a choice of changing their constitution, and a referendum is a democratic way forward. Let us stay out of things that do not concern us, and let us stop making statements that can only make a serious situation worse.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, 2019 was a year that saw a wave of protests in all corners of the world, in very different countries in levels of development, democratic culture and wealth. A social revolution is also under way in the Republic of Guinea, with a growing demand for participatory democracy. Since 14 October, demonstrations have been held across the country against the unjust constitutional reform of President Alpha Condé. Protests marked by serious acts of violence on the part of the demonstrators, but above all by the security forces. We have seen that, as unfortunately all too often happens, the authority's preferred response is simply the violent repression of dissent, with arbitrary arrests and restrictions on fundamental freedoms.  Ladies and gentlemen, the situation is extremely worrying. We must follow strongly what is happening, demand an inclusive dialogue between all the social forces and work with international regional actors to avoid civil war, but above all we must demand that our companies stop exporting arms to countries where they can be used against the people and against public opinion.

name: Thierry MARIANI
text: Madam President, the era of Sékou Touré is now a long way off and that of French influence in Africa is moving away. Today, Guinea-Conakry faces a heavy legacy, a desire to emancipation from colonial tutelage and severe difficulties in meeting the promises that the State has made to the various components of Guinean society. At the heart of the constant imbalances between its components, Guinea-Conakry is subject to very heavy foreign interference that does not help the situation. European nations and the United States may be intellectually opposed to the upcoming referendum in the country, but Guinea-Conakry is independent and that nation can freely choose to amend its constitution, if that is its wish. Today, President Alpha Condé is the subject of a great deal of criticism for his management of public order. Yes, violence against protesters is unacceptable, but the violations of public order by protesters, as some documents reveal, are equally unacceptable. So do we just want to continue to have an influence in Africa, or do we want to finally erase ourselves from China, Russia or India? Why, moreover, are we outraged by this constitutional reform, as one of my colleagues said, when, since 2000, more than 10 countries have decided to change their constitutions and certain leaders, to extend their presence in power - may I recall, for example, that in Cameroon it has been the same leader for 38 years? This resolution illustrates, once again, our powerlessness. If today we want to have a role, there is a referendum that must give the Guinean people the opportunity to choose or reject this constitutional reform, and I think we would be honoured to make this referendum happen legally, honestly - but then it is up to the Guineans to choose their constitution.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Madam President, I am thinking a little bit about why we have opened this debate. I think we want to have influence in Africa. We really want Africa to go through this development from that colonial period to the democratic period. For example, I was personally very excited when President Condé took power in Guinea in 2010 and saw the steps he was taking. I felt that, in fact, the situation in this country, which, by the way, is very beautiful and full of mineral wealth, is just beginning to change.  I am quite consternated by what started to happen in October. After all, it is not normal for people to be killed, that the repression that has occurred in the police force has been so great that indeed many of the people who were injured in the demonstrations did not have access to health care or lawyers. That is why we are going to open up this debate and appeal to Guinea to really try to prevent violence.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, African rulers who, one day ago, were democratically elected but have since maneuvered to be re-elected over and over again, and are apprehended to modify constitutions and convene pseudo-requisheds to prolong themselves in power indefinitely, are a decisive link in the chain that explains the instability, repression, suffering caused to their populations; with these mass protests of which the 2009 massacre was paroxysistic, with 150 dead and more than a hundred women raped, and the protests that took place in 2019 and this year 2020. It is imperative that the European Union acts at source to prevent this flow of migrants and asylum seekers which is currently reflecting this uptick in the Canary Islands, thinking that they are arriving in the European Union. And that means effective diplomacy that supports freedom, democracy and stability, in Guinea and across the African continent.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Madam President, the resolution condemns the ongoing violence in the Republic of Guinea and the breaches of human rights. I condemn the breach of human rights everywhere, but this Parliament loves condemning human rights abuses halfway around the world but chooses to bury its head in the sand in relation to the same human rights abuses in the EU’s own Member States. Since November 2018, French police have regularly attacked protesters against Macron’s neoliberal reforms with rubber bullets, LBD guns, GLI-F4 grenades and tear gas. The French journalist, David Dufresne, keeps count of injuries and deaths caused by the French police. The latest figures are two dead; 315 head injuries, including fractured skulls; 24 people have lost an eye; and five people have lost a hand. The resolution urges the Guinea Government to recognise the fundamental rights to freedom. Why don’t we ask the French Government to do the same? And why don’t we ask the Spanish Government to treat the Catalan protesters with fairness?

name: Mick WALLACE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the European Union is a long-standing partner of Guinea, a country that has made major progress since the first democratic elections in 2010 that brought to power the current President Alpha Condé. The country’s stability and prosperity is important for the region, as it is for the European Union. Since the 2018 local elections, the sociopolitical situation has become increasingly tense. The prospect of a new constitution, raising the possibility for President Condé to remain in power beyond the end of his second and last mandate, united opposition forces and the National Front for the Defence of the Constitution and led to frequent demonstrations against a third mandate. These demonstrations have often been severely dispersed by security forces. Opponents have been detained, and fundamental freedoms, in particular freedom of expression, were not respected. Since mid-October 2019, around 30 demonstrators have lost their lives, allegedly killed by firearms by the security forces. The EU has repeatedly called for appropriate investigations to clarify the circumstances of these incidents and to hold those responsible accountable. In such a context, preparations for legislative elections, due on 1 March, only increased the tension. Referring to strong doubts about the credibility of the voter list, two main opposition parties declared a boycott on the scrutiny. Although EU electoral missions in 2015 and 2018 recommended a thorough review of the electoral rolls, which did not accurately reflect the electorate, such a review was only very partially conducted. The recent announcement that legislative elections will be coupled to a referendum on a new draft constitution presented in December, giving ground to President Condé’s intentions, has further divided the country. There is now a clear risk of widespread instability and polarisation, including, dangerously, along ethnic lines. The EU has consistently, together with local partners – the UN, the African Union, the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS), the US and France – called for calm and has facilitated dialogue among the parties. The confidence of all in a credible and transparent electoral process is the best way to achieve participation and acceptance of the result. While every country has the right to amend or modernise its constitution, changing the fundamental law should build on an inclusive consultation leading to a large consensus, which is absent to date. Holding a referendum months before Presidential elections is not in line with the good practices recommended by the African Union and ECOWAS. In particular, the West African region has gained its democratic credentials upon these principles. It is in this context that the spokesperson of High Representative Borrell last Friday called for an inclusive dialogue to avoid further escalation of violence and to ensure conditions for transparent elections in which all parties can participate. Only a climate where political and civic space is respected and human rights violations come to an end can create conditions conducive for such a dialogue. In order to reach this, all actors should put the unity and the peace of Guinea first. We remain ready to contribute to such a process, working with our partners: the UN, the African Union and ECOWAS. The European Union remains strongly engaged in Guinea, also working with civil society and human rights defenders and with support for the resilience of the population. The Guinea crisis should remain high on our agenda.

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place at the end of the debate.

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on child labour in the Mines of Madagascar (2020/2552 (RSP)).

name: Dominique BILDE
text: Author. Madam President, Julie is 13 years old, but she will not go back to school. For 20 euro cents a day, she will now take the path of the mine, in the suffocating heat of the Malagasy summer. As for eight-year-old Frédéric, his skinned hands bear the scars of mica careers in which 11,000 young miners burn themselves slowly. Moreover, they are only a fraction of the approximately 73 million children enlisted worldwide in dangerous work, in violation of international law. It is difficult to throw the stone at the Malagasy state, whose efforts were recognized in 2016 by the U.S. Department of Labor. The fault lies with global production chains that blithely trample on our laws as well as our values. In this case, 87% of Madagascar's mica exports flock to China to supply us with electronic equipment. Our beautiful principles, established as treaties, will remain a dead letter as long as this race reigns supreme in the least social race, in defiance of ethics and humanity.

name: Caroline ROOSE
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we all agree in this Parliament that we must fight against child labour in Madagascar. The situation is unsustainable and cannot last any longer. Any setback would be unacceptable. Commission President Ursula von der Leyen has announced a zero-tolerance policy on child labour, but it would be hypocritical to say this without providing sufficient resources. A first tool is trade agreements. They must all include the issue of child labour through binding and enforceable chapters on human rights and sustainable development. A second tool is the duty of care of companies. It must be mandatory; several states are asking for it. Businesses must control their supply and be put in front of their responsibilities, in accordance with OECD standards. A third tool is the binding treaty on multinationals and human rights currently being negotiated at the United Nations. The Council must give the Commission a mandate to move forward on this treaty and reach a speedy adoption. We need a strong resolution from this Parliament: let us get to work.

name: Evin INCIR
text: Author. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for What if your phone or car exists at the expense of other people's lives! At least 11,000 children work today in the mines of Madagascar, which enable many of our phones and cars. I'm ashamed!  What the children who work in madagascar's mines are exposed to is inhumane. It's pure slavery. Children do not belong in the mines or in the labour market at all. Children belong in schools, where they will have the opportunity to grow and realize their dreams. The whole of society has a responsibility here: states, the private sector and the international community. We need to get to grips with the root of the problem, which is spelled poverty, among other things, as well as remedial efforts. Businesses, both European and non-European, must ensure that they assume their responsibilities throughout the business chain. It is not possible at all to renounce respect for human rights. Human rights, children's rights, should be respected and are not something that can be negotiated. They should simply be respected. If there is one issue on which we should be able to agree in this Parliament, it is precisely the question of how we treat the most vulnerable in our societies – namely children.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Author. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab It is rare in politics to deal with situations such as such a white and black film. There is no explanation here and there are no circumstances to justify this situation. I think that each of us, or almost all of us, has children, grandchildren, remembers these children just at the age of a couple, or even less. Let's think if they could work. Of course not. So I think that here on this issue we should speak out, very unequivocally, with a voice of moral opposition, but also of political pressure to make this situation impossible. Our economic and humanitarian aid to this country must be made conditional on the cessation of such practices.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: author. – Madam President, while we talk here indeed there are 11 000 children breathing the dusty air of the mica mines in Madagascar. Some of them are just five years old. They endure most unhealthy unsafe working conditions in the hope of earning a living for their families. How much longer can we ignore the fate of children mining mica for our companies? As the second highest importer of mica from Madagascar, the European Union, and in particular Estonia, have to take responsibility to establish a precise legal framework so that our companies possess only ethically-sourced materials. We need binding legislation on due diligence if we want to be serious about a zero-tolerance policy towards child labour as a concrete reality. We must implement fair trade policies that encourage the trade of ethical products, striving to fulfil the United Nations sustainable development goals. We urge the Commission to start a specific dialogue also with China and other important importers of mica and with the Government of Madagascar to work together to tackle and eliminate the exploitation of child labour in Madagascar by 2030.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: author. – (start of speech inaudible) this resolution Parliament strongly condemns the unacceptable use of child labour in all its forms. We remind the Malagasy authorities of their responsibility to uphold the rights of children and guarantee their safety and integrity. A significant number of children are active in mica mines. The rise in exports of this resource, combined with a significant decrease in the price per tonne, has aggravated the risk of labour exploitation. Working conditions in the mines are usually deplorable and threaten the life, health and safety of children. They are constantly exposed to chronic respiratory infections, severe injuries and dehydration and face psychological and physical abuse. Elimination of poverty is the only way to create the conditions necessary for the eradication of child labour. This requires a comprehensive approach and targeted measures in the areas of education, employment and social protection. Madagascar has made some progress by adopting a new decree reinforcing legislation against child labour and raising the legal age for employment from 15 to 16 years. In addition, Madagascar is revising its mining code, and we call on the government to prioritise the compliance with its international commitments, including in terms of social and environmental standards, decent work and respect of human and children’s rights. However, so far, the authorities have failed to apply sanctions due to a lack of resources for effective monitoring and poor law enforcement capacity. We as the European Union can also do our part. With this resolution, the Parliament calls on the EU to step up its support for projects and initiatives aimed at combating child labour in Madagascar. The EU has been actively committed to the fight against child labour through its development and trade policies, and this approach would be fully in line with the European Commission President’s pledge to have zero tolerance for child labour in EU trade policy. Nobody – and certainly no child – deserves to work in inhumane and life-threatening environments. The fight against child labour and exploitation remains an essential element of our political approach, and with this resolution we send a strong message to the world.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Author. Mr President, we all know the images. We've seen them before. Children in the mines. I saw them myself. Children in a row, drawn from small to large. Almost like at school, but it was to go work in the mine. It was to see who was just small enough to go into that nasty dark tunnel. If you've seen that, I swear to you, you'll make it a priority to eliminate child labor by 2025.  If you look at the numbers, 152 million children worldwide are in child labour. That's one in ten kids worldwide who go to work instead of going to school instead of playing. That is why I would like to thank all the co-petitioners. These were difficult negotiations, we can say that here. It was on the cutting edge, with a lot of women and a lot of women's power, but we made a strong resolution around Madagascar, around eleven thousand children in the micamins.  Let us help Madagascar, one of the poorest countries in the world, to eliminate child labour. One in two kids works there. But let us also, as Europe itself, take our measures here. I turn to the Commission: Mrs Ursula von der Leyen, of whom I am a fan, has promised to make it a priority. I ask you: before the great holiday with the European Commission's action plan, so that we can eradicate child labour by 2025.

name: Seán KELLY
text: thar ceann an Ghrúpa PPE. – A Uachtaráin, tá sé seo ar cheann de na rúin phráinneacha is truamhéalaí a phléamar sa Pharlaimint seo, mar bhaineann sé le leanaí agus go háirithe le saothar éignithe leanaí sa chás seo, sna mianaigh míoca i Madagascar. Buachaillí agus cailíní atá chomh hóg le cúig bliana d’aois ag obair sna mianaigh. Meastar go bhfuil seasca dó faoin gcéad de na mianadóirí faoi bhun ocht mbliana déag d’aois. Is scannal é mar ní thugann sé aon seans dóibh dul ar scoil agus a dtallann agus a mbuanna a úsáid amach anseo. Cuireann sé isteach ar a sláinte, go háirithe a scamhóga, agus ní fhásann siad i gceart, agus bíonn siad ag obair ar thuarastal an-íseal. Dá bhrí sin, is ceart agus is cóir go gcuirfimid romhainn deireadh a chur leis an gcleachtas seo, saothar éignithe leanaí, faoi 2025. Is sprioc é seo dúinn a Choimisinéir, agus má éiríonn linn é sin a dhéanamh, beidh gaisce déanta againn.

name: Maria ARENA
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D- Madam President, I am very angry about the debate we have today.  I agree that child labour in Madagascar is unacceptable, but, ladies and gentlemen, when a law on compulsory due diligence, that is, the duty of vigilance of companies, had to be passed, the right - the Renew Group, the EPP Group - voted against it! When yesterday we had to add chapters on sustainable development, with sanctions, that prevent child labour in Vietnam, the Renew Group and the EPP Group voted against it! When it takes a battle to enshrine corporate responsibility and corporate traceability in international trade treaties, the Renew Group and the EPP vote against it! When it came to establishing the traceability of blood minerals, the EPP Group and the Renew Group - in part, not all - voted against it! So listen! Excuse me, but working against child labour and making a resolution that is by no means binding is mere hypocrisy! I will support it because it is important, but I think it is hypocritical of our Parliament to have an attitude like this.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, Madam Commissioner, 47% of Malagasy children aged 5 to 17 are working, instead of in school.  Not only are they deprived of an education but for many, they risk their lives on a daily basis in dangerous jobs such as mining. Every child has a right to an education, a right to a standard of living that supports their physical, mental, and social development. Child labour violates these rights.  The EU has committed to ending child labour by 2025, but this means five more years of suffering for millions of children in Madagascar and beyond, and many more lives lost and futures ruined.  Let’s put an end to child labour even sooner. Let’s do everything we can to support countries to accelerate their implementation of legislation and actions that will achieve this goal.  So the Renew Europe group says let’s put the commitments of the Commission into more meaningful action.

name: Maxette PIRBAKAS
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the subject we are dealing with calls into question our global production model based solely on the economy. Making children work to export the cheapest possible products in Europe, with a less-called social, environmental and human: this is the ultraliberal and productive model that the European Union defends and which leads to situations of exploitation of child labour, as is the case in the mines in Madagascar. So is making children work, is that the economic model the European Union wants? Getting children to work? For the Identity and Democracy group, the future is pragmatic localism, not globalism without borders. For us, it is time to find intelligent protectionism that alerts consumers to the source of imports of products from the work of miners. How can we talk about ecology in this Chamber when human beings are not respected? How can we continue to allow products of materials from the exploitation of child labour to enter Europe? With a Europe of nations and intelligent protectionism based on fair trade and localism, that would not happen. With a Europe that protects its peoples and nations, with a Commission at the service of States and not the other way around, that would not happen. So, ladies and gentlemen, listen to your peoples and their vote; it is time to act.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, the human and environmental price of our modern telephones and shiny cars is obviously becoming really intolerable, because we know that it is produced with child labour – with forced labour – without any knowledge by the consumers of where these products actually originate. If the Parliament really takes itself seriously by today calling for any part of their production from these mines to be directly or indirectly brought into the EU market, we can only think of the mandatory human rights due diligence, which that the Chairwoman of the Subcommittee on Human Rights has referred to. So let’s not be hypocritical: if we want to eradicate child labour, we can do it, but we need to put the instruments in place, and there’s nothing better than mandatory human rights due diligence legislation at the EU level.

name: Adam BIELAN
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Child labour in the Republic of Madagascar is a common problem. More than 230,000 children are used in mining. Children from the age of 10 are employed in gold, stone and sapphire mines. As a result, they often live in poverty, suffer from respiratory problems and diseases such as malaria, and are also forced to work in dangerous conditions. Although the Malagasy authorities have introduced legislation regulating the working conditions of children over the age of 15, its scope and enforcement are insufficient to solve the problem. Today we call on the Republic of Madagascar to respect the rights of children, to guarantee their safety and adequate education, and to act in accordance with their obligations under international conventions and agreements. Furthermore, we call on the Commission to ensure that the european Union's future strategy for Africa is based on ambitions in line with the SDGs and emphasises the rights of the child.

name: Ivan Vilibor SINČIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, the fact that in Madagascar children work 12 hours each in dark, hot and poisonous jams for 40 cents a day is a disgrace to all humanity. That's not the only example. In the Congo, cobalt is mined, and the Chinese who mostly reprocess it all are also exploited. The common name of all this misery and injustice is neoliberalism. It is an outdated and missed system that destroys everything national, social, traditional and environmental. It's a system that, for the profits of a few today, destroys everyone's future. It is a system that undermines society and the environment and is the enemy of all life on earth. It's a system that's the antithesis of sustainability that's talked about so much here.  We must look for the future in a profound change in the financial system and in decentralising ownership of raw materials, food and energy.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab More than one million children in Madagascar are forced to work, thousands of them working in mines in dangerous conditions. The Malagasy authorities have already made some progress and are willing to solve the problem. However, more decisive action is needed. We therefore call on the Malagasy authorities to scrutiny the situation in depth, to investigate abuse and to obtain permits from child labour mines. The problem of forced labour is inextricably linked to poverty. According to the UNICEF report, as many as 27% of Madagascar's population lives in extreme poverty and as many as 47% of children suffer from chronic malnutrition. The problem of child labour cannot be eliminated without eliminating poverty. The European Union should continue its development support to Madagascar. Access to education must be one of the priorities of this aid. This is important not only for the development of each child, but also for the overall development of the country.

name: Bettina VOLLATH
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her If 11 000 children in Madagascar and 150 million children worldwide, including for our consumption, were sick or even put to death, then that is also a failure of Europe. I therefore call on the Council to give the Commission an urgent clear mandate so that it can participate constructively in the ongoing UN negotiations for a binding agreement for transnational companies and the development of real solutions. Incidentally, I very much regret that the Council is not taking part in the debate today. On a voluntary basis, it still does not work to keep global supply chains free of child suffering and exploitation. So we need commitment, rules and sanctions. The unconditional ban on child labour must finally become a mandatory condition of our international trade relations, because anyone who talks about children's rights one day and adopts exploitative trade agreements the next day is hypocritical. The focus on profit must be behind the protection of children's lives, health, education and good progress.

name: Robert BIEDROŃ
text: – Madam President, work in adulthood is called, well, work, but work during childhood should be called what it should be: play, education and development. Therefore, the phrase ‘child labour’ is an oxymoron in itself. Unfortunately, children as young as five make up more than half the number of miners in Madagascar. This means that at least 11 000 children are extracting mica, a mineral which is used for everything from make up to car paint. Do you know what this means? Those children are working for us – Europeans – as well. In Madagascar people strongly depend on mining and the income it provides, but the exploitation of children must stop, and we must start to stop it here, and stop our own hypocrisy, adopting legislation which will ban child exploitation worldwide.

name: Elżbieta RAFALSKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab There can be no excuse for the exploitation that child labour should be regarded as – often very hard and dangerous work. According to the International Labour Organisation, more than 351 million economically active children are employed worldwide, including 170 million children in dangerous work. This shows us the scale of the problem. We have such a dramatic situation in Madagascar, where the poverty rate is very high at 74%. And it is poverty that is considered the most important cause of child labour. Due to extreme poverty, even one in three children is malnourished in Madagascar, mothers at birth die 100 times more often than in Poland – in the country where I come from. Malnutrition of children under 5 years is common. Children work hard, in dangerous conditions, most often in mica mining. Our calls for the Government of Madagascar to protect the rights of the child and to eliminate work must become more effective.

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: I have six requests from three groups for the following procedure of spontaneous speeches. I would like to make it clear again that I should take one speech per group. I look at the Commissioner to see if she can cope with a relatively short reply. I would like to do so now if it does not contradict. Spontaneous speeches

name: Ljudmila NOVAK
text: – Madam President! My country Slovenia is a small country, and yet we have very close links with Madagascar, because quite a few Slovenian priests work as missionaries in Madagascar. Not only are they priests, they also care about people's well-being.  The best example is missionary Peter Brick, who picks up people at the dump and then organizes them. The whole village of Akamasoa has been created – good friends, where parents get a modest house, then they get a job and the children go to school. The teachers are local women and teachers, so he organized his life: children go to schools, and the rest of the adults have some work to do. And I think this is the best, most appropriate pattern of aiding in the Third World. He is also inspired by the Malagasy government and the Pope.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in Madagascar, one of the poorest countries in the world, even though child labour is officially banned, almost a quarter of children between the age of five and seventeen are forced to work on vanilla plantations, quarries, on the street or as domestic servants. And the reality of the thousands of children who work every day in mica mines, many of them completely irregular, in very harsh conditions and dangerous to their health, is dramatic. For just 4 cents a kilo, these children are forced to cut the ore and clean the debris with their hands, reporting wounds and breathing harmful fine dust on a daily basis. The 1989 UN Convention, of which we have just mentioned the 30th anniversary, cannot only be celebrated and the protection of children's rights cannot stop at Europe's borders. The Union must act to put an end to these unacceptable violations by activating the necessary policies to make the industry that uses these materials responsible and to support the poorest countries. Commissioner, we must all work to really implement the rights of children enshrined in the UN Convention.

name: Clare DALY
text: – Madam President, I wouldn’t say anybody here has ever met a person who supports child labour, but yet it continues. For God’s sake, yesterday we agreed an agreement with a country where child labour exists. Where is the questioning about why this happens? Do you think the parents of the children in Madagascar don’t love them? That they don’t want them to go to school? Of course they do, but they have no alternative, because their children are the victims of capitalism, of industrial agriculture, of climate change and drought. And we have multi—nationals from European countries doing business there. Now I’m sorry, but I have to say these motions are pathetic. Appealing to their better nature is like asking a wolf not to eat a goat. It lets us down badly. Where’s the penalties? Where’s the criminal charges? Where’s the binding legislation? Will you cop yourselves on? They don’t need crocodile tears, they need action.

name: Clare DALY
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, in recent months we have seen some serious and disturbing revelations about the exploitation of children involved in mica extraction in Madagascar. We cannot tolerate a situation where children are forced... (The President interrupted the speaker to call for Members to take their seats) Thank you. We cannot tolerate a situation where children are forced to work in horrendous conditions and are deprived of an education. Prompt action is needed, but we also need to address root causes. On the nearly 46 000 tonnes of mica which Madagascar exported in 2018, more than 91% was shipped to China, according to the International Trade Centre. The principal question to address is therefore one of due diligence in the supply chain. However, boosting the capacity and accountability of State institutions in Madagascar, including through our development cooperation will also be key. As many Members will be aware, the EU has already taken positive action to address supply chain risks in relation to the so-called conflict minerals, such as tin, tungsten, tantalum and gold, and the EU regulation covering due diligence for these will come into force next year. (The President again called for Members to take their seats quietly) We cannot stand by while child labour - an oxymoron as Robert Biedroń rightly put it - child labour in the extractive industries continues. There is an urgent need for international companies sourcing mica and mica-based products, as well as the Malagasy government to take responsibility for addressing the problematic conditions, and for contributing to improving the fulfilment of children’s rights. The European Union has a long-standing and clear position on due diligence. Not only governments but also private actors have a role to play. The European Parliament hosted an important event in November 2019 in which the urgency of addressing child labour in mica mining was prominently raised. Commission President von der Leyen made it clear that the EU has zero tolerance for child labour. The EU led the tabling of a resolution on the Rights of the Child, adopted in the United Nations General Assembly 3rd Committee last year, where 2021 was declared the International Year for the Elimination of Child Labour. The Commission will shortly publish a study on due diligence requirements through the supply chain. It examines existing regulation and proposals, as well as options for regulating due diligence in companies own operations, and through the supply chain for adverse human rights and environmental impacts, including relating to climate change. In a single market, it is not practical to have different national treatments, and the benefits of an EU-wide framework are obvious in terms of levelling the playing field and creating legal certainty for companies, as well as reaping opportunities stemming from the sustainability transition. The EU is of course also fully behind a multi-stakeholder initiative to address supply chains risk, and in particular child labour. We will continue to work spanning trade agreements, development projects and other international cooperation, in Madagascar and elsewhere, to tackle root causes such as the social and economic vulnerability of individuals, workers and their families that put children to work. (Applause)

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place at the end of the debate. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Atidzhe ALIEVA-VELI
text: in writing. – The exploitation of child labour is completely inadmissible, no matter where in the world it takes place. Shockingly, according to figures provided by the International Labour Organisation, an estimated 152 million children aged between five and 17 are victims of child labour. The alarming revelations about approximately 11,000 children subjected to extremely difficult working conditions at mines in Madagascar, and the fact that children make up about 62% of the total workforce in the mines, require immediate and immediate measures. I believe that the EU cannot remain indisturbed when the facts show that children are working to exhaustion, are being lowered into unsecured mines, exposed to harsh and dangerous working conditions causing back pain, headaches due to heat and lack of water or oxygen in mines, muscle aches, respiratory problems, risk of death as a result of landslides. I call on the EU to encourage and assist Madagascar in adopting and effectively implementing legislative and immediate action programmes in order to eradicate the exploitation of child labour and protect all children's rights. I believe that the EU, as the world's main human rights defender, should take the lead in the eradication of child labour. I insist that the eradication of the exploitation of child labour is at the heart of the forthcoming EU strategy for Africa.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Madagascar is the third largest exporter of mica in the world, with revenue estimated at USD 6.5 million in 2017. Almost 90% of all mica mined in Madagascar is exported directly to China, where its price is almost 500 times higher than the initial value when traveling to China. However, this lucrative business works at the expense of minors and children. Half of the 20,000 people working in mica mining are children involved in its extraction and sorting, and only 30% of Malagasy children have access to primary school, making them have no chance of breaking out of the vicious circle. The extraction and processing of mica is considered one of the worst forms of child labour primarily because of the risks involved. Children up to 5 years of age work in very difficult conditions, with low oxygen levels and high dust levels, are exposed to silicica, carry heavy loads and tools. The exploitation of minors for work in all its forms is unacceptable and those responsible should suffer the consequences.

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: The Renew Europe Group has notified the President of the following decisions relating to changes to appointments:  - Katalin Cseh replaces Nicola Danti in the Committee on Foreign Affairs - Nicola Danti replaces Katalin Cseh in the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy These decisions shall take effect on the date of this announcement. ***

name: Antonius MANDERS
text: Mr President, a point of order. Can you ask the services to put a spam filter on our emails, because we've been overwhelmed in the last few months with all kinds of emails that are all the same. It is easy for us to take technical measures against this. There is no point in receiving 600 identical emails, and it hinders us in our work. (Beifall)

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: We took note. I will inform the services about that. Just an additional point for information on that: you can still set up your own filtering rules if you wish. (Applause)

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: The next item is the vote.  (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes)

name: Nuno MELO
text: – Mr President, my voting machine didn’t work in the last vote – it’s true – so you must count my vote too, please.

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: According to the Rules of Procedure, the result of the vote does not change. Did your machine work in other votes or was this the only one when it didn’t work?

name: Nuno MELO
text: – Mr President, a sneaky way of winning, but ok.

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: Those are the Rules of Procedure. If your machine doesn’t work, try to find another seat.

name: Daniel FREUND
text: – Mr President, on the roll call vote we just did, just to check, the wrong amendment was announced on the screen. We voted on the first one, not the second one.

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: What was on the screen, we checked on the second part if I remember correctly. OK, we continue. That concludes the vote.

name: Bogdan RZOŃCA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I very much welcome the news that Frontex will have another instrument to combat fraudsters. Document fraud is one of the most cost-effective for criminals. I would like to point out that poor people do not take advantage of this type of opportunity. People do it for money, who just make money from scams. This is very dangerous for the whole of the European Union, for the whole world, and criminals who lead to situations where they allow the use of false documents to criminals or people who simply have something to hide, who are operating illegally, violate European, global and local public order. This is a very good resolution, a very good instrument. And I am pleased that Frontex will be able to analyse all criminal situations in the European Union in more depth.

name: Joachim Stanisław BRUDZIŃSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Of course, I voted in favour of solutions that will allow the fight against criminals, with offences related to illegal documents. Today, the coastguard, the services of individual nation states, must cooperate in order to be able to fight this type of crime effectively. It should be made very clear here that both Frontex and the services of the individual countries responsible for the security of online documents must be a step ahead of criminals. In view of the above, it is appropriate to call on the Commission, indeed, to implement this regulation as soon as possible in order to give instruments to the relevant states, to the relevant services.

name: Guido REIL
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I voted against this resolution. Of course, we are in favour of women's rights and we must support them. But here such a nonsense is called for as early childhood sex education in order to support their gender identity. So for me, that's sick stuff. We have very different problems. In Germany, for example, a woman is murdered every third day. The number of murders has risen sharply since 2013, and domestic violence cases in Germany have risen sharply since 2014. In 2014, there were 103,000 cases, and in 2018 there were 114,000 cases. The perpetrators are mostly migrants. And it is not only the perpetrators who are migrants, but also, for the most part, the victims. I have numbers from my hometown of Essen. 70% of the women who seek protection in women's shelters are migrant women. These are real problems and we must point out real problems.

name: Virginie JORON
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this so-called European Parliament wants to present a resolution at the 64th conference at the United Nations on the status of women.  In this text, nothing is found about the thousands of murdered young women. Nothing about Laura, this 16-year-old girl slit her throat at the end of a grassy esplanade in Sallaumines. Sallaumines is not in Iraq, it is not in Afghanistan, it is not in Colombia, it is not in the Bronx. Sallaumines is in Europe; Sallaumines is here in France. One thousand assaults every day in France, 140 sexual violence every day in France. These dramas, these horrors, these murderers, we know them.  You are asking us, and I quote, to institutionalise intersectional analysis in all THE bodies of the United Nations and in the European Union. What does that mean? You want to label people - a quarter European, three-quarters single, a quarter female, three-quarters privileged? You're talking about eternal imaginary victims with your scraps of paper. You tolerate the abusers still assaulting. French women will remember that.  I therefore supported the resolution of our ECR allies and voted against it.

name: Eugen TOMAC
text: – Mr President, I voted for this resolution.  I believe that it is essential to continue to pay close attention to policies by combating gender discrimination of any kind. So women need to be protected. We still have women in Europe who come from poor areas, who face this daily discrimination, have no representation, do not have adequate remuneration, do not have a fair system in terms of retirement, so there is still this problem, including in Europe, and we need to give it due attention. So I am for the greatest representation for women, I am to combat violence of any kind, and I believe that only through policies implemented to a high standard that we have can we combat this phenomenon.

name: Leila CHAIBI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this is the second time in three weeks that a resolution on equality between men and women has been voted on. At the last plenary session, it was a text on income inequality between men and women and today it is a text on the priorities of the European Union for the 64th session of the UN Committee on the Status of Women. Once again, in this text, which was voted by a large majority in this House, I read that the solution to reduce inequalities between men and women is to increase women's pensions and, moreover, to develop reversion pensions - those allowances that are paid to a widow or a widower when the spouse dies. I have seen that the French colleagues of the Renew group, of the Republic on the move, voted for this text as we do, and I want to denounce here the double discourse: the double discourse because these colleagues vote for this resolution and, at the same time, in France, the government they represent, that of Emmanuel Macron, is restricting access to pensions of reversion with his pension reform. Stop this double discourse, if we really want to make gender equality a reality.

name: Juozas OLEKAS
text: – Dear President. Gender equality is not only the foundation of society, but also a necessary means of development, promotion and poverty reduction. We recommend that the Council work more actively towards equality between men and women and combating various discrimination, stepping up efforts to close the gender pay and pension gaps, and ensuring equal pay. It is also to promote the education of girls and women, especially in areas where they are clearly under-represented. I strongly condemn all forms of violence against women and girls, including trafficking in human beings, sexual exploitation, forced marriages, child marriages, female genital mutilation and the use of sexual violence as a weapon of war.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on road safety (2020/2563(RSP)). I remind you that it’s possible to request catch-the-eye and blue cards using both the standard registration and the electronic system. Instructions are available at the entrance to the Hemicycle.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for putting on the agenda such an important topic for you and for myself as a Commissioner for Transport, especially because you are giving me the opportunity to share my thoughts with you before I travel to Stockholm on 19 February for the 3rd Global Ministerial Conference on Road Safety.  It is our duty to do everything needed to protect the lives and well-being of European citizens. 25 000 people who lose their lives on European roads and 135 000 suffering severe injuries, are numbers which are unacceptable for us and of course we need to do more in terms of action and support. Road safety will therefore be a priority in my mandate and, with your help we can make it a priority for the whole Union.
