Let’s not forget though that Europe has made enormous progress in road safety over the last decade. We are the safest region in the world and we have a lot of experience and good practice to share. This is an opportunity for true European leadership. Globally 1.35 million people are dying on the roads every year. In fact, road crashes are the biggest killer of young people worldwide. The global target to reduce road fatalities by 50% - part of the Sustainable Development Goals - is expiring this year, and this target was not and will not be reached.  This must not mean that we are ready to reduce our ambition. Europe needs to be at the forefront of supporting a new ambitious global fatality reduction target and I intend to say this very clearly in Stockholm. The Swedish Minister for Infrastructure intends to present in Stockholm a so-called ‘Stockholm Declaration’, which calls for renewed efforts and a new global target. I very much support this declaration and I hope that it will be adopted as it is planned. The next step will be a resolution at the UN General Assembly. The Commission will also very much support the process leading up to such a resolution, including through our offices in Geneva and in New York. Ultimately, what counts is results.  In Europe, we are implementing the safe system approach, which is a holistic system building cooperation, good governance and shared responsibility. It addresses all areas – infrastructure, vehicles, behaviour and post-crash care.  The Safe System accepts that human error will happen and compensates for it. Drivers and other road users will continue to make mistakes on the road as they do elsewhere, because to err is human and distractions, alcohol and drugs increase the risk of error, but no road user deserves to die because of a mistake.  As you know, the EU transport ministers have unanimously supported our new EU-wide targets to halve the number of fatalities and for the first time serious injuries by 2030, and the Commission has followed up with an ambitious action plan. The first concrete actions have already been taken. Last year, thanks to strong support from the European Parliament, we strengthened the EU rules on both safe infrastructure management and vehicle safety. We’ll continue to promote ambitious legislation in this mandate and I look forward to discuss with you details in the future.  But in the meantime, let us work in partnership which is indeed the essence of the safe system approach to road safety. As legislators you are well equipped to push us all, the Commission, the Member States, industry, NGOs, to deliver on more ambitious targets and of course, to promote ambition in action in our constituencies. Looking ahead, it is clear that mobility is going through profound change. Climate change demands that we reduce emissions, while digitalisation is opening up new opportunities for easier cleaner and safer mobility. As society shifts, so will the focus of road safety. We need to look at new transport trends in towns and cities and what they mean for vulnerable road users, and we need to consider the implications of autonomous vehicles.  We need to drive the change and make sure change does not hamper our zero-victims vision.  I look forward to a good exchange with you this afternoon and I really appreciate the fact that you put this point on the agenda.

name: Róża THUN UND HOHENSTEIN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I opened a newspaper today and this is what I read in bold: ‘In the first 40 days of this year, 100 pedestrians were killed by cars on Polish roads. Sixty percent of those mortal traffic accidents took place at pedestrian crossings’. I’m also happy that we put this point during today’s session, because road safety is a matter of life and death in the most literal sense of the word, and the situation on our European roads is dramatic. So last year the European Union adopted the world’s most advanced mandatory vehicle-safety requirements, the General Safety Regulation. You will remember that it will become applicable in July 2022 and will reduce the number of deaths on the roads significantly. But many say that even the best technical solutions will not improve the situation on the roads if the road users behave in an irresponsible way. I hear very often that the European Union must educate. But, unfortunately, the European institutions do not have competences in education, TV and radio programmes, the organisation of driving licence courses etc. We must cooperate with our Member States much more closely in order to achieve a significant reduction in fatalities on the roads. Yes, Commissioner, it is our aim to achieve the vision zero goal and we should prepare a detailed roadmap of how to achieve this as soon as possible. We have positive examples from cities like London, Helsinki and Oslo. They have managed to reduce, or even eradicate, the number of fatalities in road accidents. Let us profit from those examples, and much success to all of us.

name: Johan DANIELSSON
text: On the other: And on the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Commissioner Vălean, thank you for your introduction. 500 people lose their lives on European roads every week. This is equivalent to two passenger planes crashing in europe every week, which would, of course, have been totally unacceptable – and that is also the figures for our roads. Globally, it's even worse. 26 000 people lose their lives every week, mainly children and young people, and mainly also people from low- and middle-income countries. Although the death toll is falling and the number of road injured is falling, the figures are still far too high. We must therefore put the issue of road safety higher on the agenda, both in Europe and globally. It is important that we in europe continue to work on the zero vision presented by the previous Commission, which Commissioner Vălean says he wants to continue to prioritise.  We must also contribute to achieving the UN Sustainable Development Goals, albeit not in time, so later – that we have new targets in place, and that we ensure that we succeed in halving the number of road fatalities and injuries at global level. I am therefore pleased that my party colleague and our Swedish Minister for Infrastructure Tomas Eneroth are hosting the global UN conference on road safety next week.  We must improve road safety for the sake of all of us: motorists, passengers, motorcyclists, cyclists, pedestrians and, not least, road workers. The majority of road accidents are, as the Commissioner said, preventable. We must also include vulnerable road users more in our overall work, as we heard from a colleague earlier in the debate. Everyone should be able to feel safe when walking or cycling to and from work or to and from their school.  With better infrastructure, with analysis of speed limits, roads become safer, but it also leads to reduced emissions. In this way, road safety work also contributes to achieving our overall climate goals.  EU funding and infrastructure investment must therefore always include a road safety perspective. We must have high safety standards and carry out customized tests and analyses on our vehicles. The latter is extremely important. In fact, although half of the world's population is women, studies show that women are currently more than 70% more likely to be killed in a car accident than men, because we do not use crash test dolls that are adapted for women. Such crash dolls now finally exist, but we must also ensure that they are used. Let us now ensure, therefore, that together we make sure that we start using the new crash dolls, so that it is equally safe to drive, whether you are a man or a woman. When it comes to road safety, we need to think about both equality and equality.  I hope that today's debate can send a signal to the UN conference next week that we must work together to achieve our global goals and to save lives. In conclusion, I would just like to say that during my speech in this House, nine people have lost their lives in traffic. There are far too many. So let us now start working together to put a stop to this.

name: Valter FLEGO
text: on behalf of the Renew Club. – The Respected Commissioner, every day on Europe's roads, about 500 people die. Unfortunately, most of us have probably lost someone close or dear to us at one point in our lives, and surely each of us fears daily for the safety of our children and families. We are in fear because we are aware of the dangers in traffic, but we are also aware of how unnecessary these deaths are, we are aware that they can and should be reduced and completely eradicated. According to a report by the World Health Organization, up to 1.35 million people die annually on European roads, and even more worrying is the fact that accidents are the most common cause of death for young people between the age of 5 and 29. In 2018 alone, there were 25,000 road deaths and 135,000 seriously injured in Europe. And it is an inadmissible and unnecessary human and social cost of mobility. The fact is that Europe's current medium-term target through a vision of zero or halving the number of road deaths from 2010 to 2020 will not be achieved. We have again set ourselves overly ambitious goals that are not attainable. Of course I agree that the goals should be motivating, but also they must be realistic and achievable and the countries that are, unfortunately, the least safe when it comes to road transport are Romania, Bulgaria and Croatia. They are also countries where there are twice as many traffic fatalities as the European average and it is not true that people in these countries do not know how to drive or drive worse than drivers in Denmark, Norway or the Netherlands. It is true that people in Romania, Bulgaria or my Croatia have a much worse fleet, have older and more unsafe cars, older and more unsafe roads that lead, unfortunately, to fatal consequences.  Dear Commissioner, there is no revolution in the transport safety segment without new breakthroughs in technologies to be used in transport and without investment in road infrastructure. And technology exists, technology is being perfected every day and it depends on all of us how fast it will take us to get that available technology and start using it. New technologies such as the sharing economy and autonomous driving are already very much in use and I am sure that they are a great solution for burdened European environments that are also affected by various diseases due to the exhaust emissions that we are fighting here in different European cities. New technologies of robotics and automation in transport can drastically reduce the human error factor that is the cause of over 90% of all traffic accidents, and if we are really going to achieve the vision of zero deaths in 2021-2030, we must continue to build a safe system at Member State level. In addition to designing and maintaining infrastructure, "fault-forgiving roads" are essential to significantly reduce the severity of an accident if it occurs, but we must also encourage fleet renewal, reduce excise duties and taxes on cars with Euro NCAP five stars, as this risk of injury is the lowest. Last but not least, let's educate our citizens. I get the impression that we all forget about this extremely important part of the fight for greater traffic safety. This may not sound as attractive as building infrastructure or applying new technologies, but it is very important because most young people in traffic today are a danger because they are unaware of how important it is to be educated. Dear Commissioner, today we no longer accept any dead in air accidents, please make it a priority in your mandate and that the same will be the same in car, truck or road traffic.

name: Tilly METZ
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. In the EU, around 500 people die on our roads every week. These are two full planes that crash. We would never accept so many deaths in aviation. Why do we accept them on the road? Every year, road accidents cost an estimated EUR 280 billion. Then there are the human and social tragedies. I therefore welcome the European Commission's commitments to halve the number of road deaths in particular during the next EU road safety policy. This medium-term goal will be the key to achieving vision zero – zero deaths – for 2050. Technological progress and artificial intelligence could significantly improve road safety, as human error plays a role in 94% of accidents. However, an automated road sector presents new risks and challenges that need to be addressed, such as new infrastructures for driverless vehicles, ethical issues relating to liability and data protection, and environmental and health problems. While pedestrians and cyclists are by far the least likely to harm other road users, they are the most vulnerable road users and account for almost a third of all deaths. In order to increase road safety and reduce the number of deaths, we need new urban planning that prioritises pedestrians, cyclists and public transport. We need an EU strategy for safe and sustainable mobility. As you yourself said, Commissioner, and I am pleased about that, you have a strategy. And policies go with action. I hope that you will remain true to what you have said and that road safety will be an important priority for you in the years to come.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Improving the safety of road users, i.e. drivers, pedestrians and cyclists, is a huge challenge for both the Member States and the European Commission. Looking at the statistics, it is easy to see that the number of road fatalities is closely linked to geography, and the least developed regions perform the worst in this comparison. Nearly 55% of road accidents in which people die occur on rural roads. There is probably no better justification for the continuation of an ambitious cohesion policy that allows local authorities to invest in safe infrastructure and public transport. Technology and advanced vehicle safety systems are also a great support for drivers. The next step will certainly be fully autonomous vehicles, but this is the future. And today we must encourage drivers, especially young people, to drive responsibly. It is worth involving in these activities, for example, insurance companies that have the tools to effectively reward safe driving. I am convinced that the European Commission can count on us in all its efforts to promote road safety and the implementation of the strategy for the elimination of fatalities by 2050.

name: Elena KOUNTOURA
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, we are in a state of emergency and we owe it to the victims to design ambitious policies and to remind them at every opportunity that road safety is a top priority for the European Parliament.  In Europe today, we have 500 deaths a week, even though our roads are the safest in the world. This figure corresponds to two air accidents a week in Europe or the disappearance of a small town of 26,000 inhabitants a year. Unfortunately, however, victims on motorways do not activate the reflexes of either the media or our society and our politicians accordingly. This situation must be reversed. Even if we accept that human error will never disappear, we envision the reduction of accidents and — above all — zero losses in human lives. The key is to move from words to practice. We have heard from the other political groups that they too want ambitious policies, but I wonder: if their intentions are sincere, why did they not support our call for a resolution on road safety? It would be an excellent opportunity to put the new Parliament on such an important issue and bring it to the fore, especially in view of the third world ministerial conference in Stockholm.  The European Parliament must be a pioneer in road safety in practice and I call on you, as a first step, to review your attitude and support concrete proposals. For example, reiterate our commitment to the European target of reducing the number of deaths and serious injuries by 1/2 from 2020 to 2030 and reducing deaths to zero by 2050. To create European programmes in the next financial framework, with the aim of promoting policies that have proven to have positive results, and specific programmes aimed at reducing the major disparities between Member States in road safety performance, i.e. where there is a great deal of room for improvement. To make use of the latest innovations in the automotive industry in safety systems in new and old vehicles, where possible. Set targets to reduce the deaths of vulnerable network users in the context of urban mobility. Establish a regulatory framework for vehicles with automated driving systems. Strengthen the application of road traffic rules both at national level and across borders.  Commissioner Vălean has already expressed twice to the Committee on Transport — as today, here in Parliament — her commitment to actively work for safer roads in Europe and I thank her from the heart for that. We in Parliament must therefore also clarify our priorities and work with the Commission and the Member States to lay the foundations for a successful strategy and an ambitious legislative framework in the coming years, which will enable us to achieve the target of halving deaths and serious injuries in 2030.

name: Benoît LUTGEN
text: Madam President, Commissioner, thank you for your statement. The strategy adopted last June aims to halve the number of deaths and serious injuries on our roads in Europe. It is a magnificent human goal, we all know about the unfortunate cases of families that have been destroyed by the reality of road and road safety. To achieve that, I think we need to take a whole range of options. The European Commission had considered, among other things, and I hope, a review of the reality of the driver's licence; a review also, no doubt, of cross-border cooperation, particularly in the case of the withdrawal of driver's licences; a review of the recommendations, too, for limiting alcohol, drugs or even speeding while driving. These are at least three avenues which I think are important and on which I hope that you will work to bring, beyond one objective, concrete measures to improve the overall situation of road safety in Europe. If we look closely, in recent years we have seen a form of stagnation in road safety figures, and we can regret that. After an improvement that has taken place for many years, this stagnation cannot continue. It cannot continue, moreover, because we have a very strong target in terms of reducing the number of deaths and injuries. May I also ask you to go further, particularly in the correlations of good practice by Member State. We need to be able to ask the right questions together. Of course, infrastructure and vehicles are not the same everywhere in the Member States, but let us recognise that some measures must also be implemented in some Member States to improve the reality of road safety and road safety figures. There are too many discrepancies, and there are very large differences in road safety between the different Member States. I very much hope, Commissioner, that we can work more on these figures and also that you can, that we can together make recommendations, Member State by Member State, so that good practices are disseminated everywhere and that the lot of road safety can be improved throughout Europe.

name: Adriana MALDONADO LÓPEZ
text: – Madam President, thank you, Commissioner, for bringing to this House a debate which I think is essential. And it is true that we often talk about many issues and talk about issues, such as road safety, right now, which is a fundamental issue in the day-to-day life of the European Union and in the day-to-day life also of our fellow citizens. As the Commissioner rightly indicated, more than 25,500 people die on European roads each year. In Spain, for example, around 71% or 91% of accidents are due to human causes. And that is where I believe that we need to focus all our efforts as a European Parliament, as a European Commission and also as a European Council. We must join all our forces from the European institutions and also from the States.  And I believe that new technologies here are going to play a key role; a key role, because we have to take into account that new models of autonomous cars are already being created. We are seeing how that human risk is the key factor in traffic accidents and therefore we need to try to reduce it as much as possible. And we have to be smart and use, from my point of view, new technologies, such as artificial intelligence, to make that human risk as small as possible in traffic accidents. Because, in short, we are talking about the lives of many people. And I think we also have to use digitization to be able to reduce that great mortality. It is also true that I believe that it is a real challenge for the internal market. I believe that we need to be able, for example, to create and ensure legal certainty, to encourage investment in the relevant technologies and also to protect citizens and consumers from the new challenges we have in everything related to road safety. I therefore believe that digitisation is a good opportunity for road safety to also be a new challenge to be addressed in the European Commission.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Madam President, there are far more people in the chamber today than there were last Thursday, and this is a step in a good direction for which I can congratulate you. Dear Commissioner, I can speak on this first-person topic as someone who has only recently had a history of road safety. For many people, this topic sounds strange and far from them, however, road safety is not just the wearing of belts and not talking on the phone while driving. Road safety is a system of legislative, educational, enforcement and, in particular, preventive measures. Road safety is the responsibility of the driver of the vehicles and of all direct and indirect road users. In my home country Bulgaria, more than 682 people have died in road accidents in 2018. By the end of October 2019, there are 511. I dare say that these figures are quite understated, unfortunately. This includes only direct victims of road accidents, not people who suffered trauma in the accident and, as a consequence, lost their lives. My country loses more of its citizens in road accidents in a year than countries where fighting is also taking place. That's, to put it mildly, unacceptable. Road safety is therefore much more important than a number of topics we are discussing in the European Union, such as the curved cucumbers or what should be in the dune sauce. Reducing or reaching 0 indicators in road traumatism wants concrete measures. For example, the unification of the road marking, the signs that are affixed throughout Europe, so this must be pursued. Dear Mrs. Valyan, we have a lot of work to do. We must pay attention to the other initiatives and documents for which you, as Commissioner, are also responsible. We must pay attention to this contradictory return of empty trucks, because this even contradicts the idea of green measures in the European Union and Parliament. I just heard comments about not complying with the women's tests. I don't think gender has anything to do with whether or not you can drive a car. I don't think women are better or worse drivers, there should just be strict rules for everyone. (The Speaker agrees to answer a blue card question (Rule 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Róża THUN UND HOHENSTEIN
text: blue-card question. – Excuse me, I just wanted to ask, when did you last discuss the curving of the cucumber and such issues in the European Parliament, because I have been here for the last almost 11 years and I never encountered such a discussion. So I wonder is this an ECR speciality or whether you discuss those?

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: answer a question asked by raising a blue card. – Dear colleague, I remind you in the last term, in this chamber, we voted and discussed what to have in the sauce of the dune, remember this? I don't think that's an essential topic. The topic we are discussing at the moment is much more substantial and more important. I can refresh your memory both in terms of curved cucumbers, and in terms of the dune, you seem to have forgotten them, 10 years is a long time. You must have missed them? But this has nothing to do with today's discussion.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Road safety is undoubtedly an important social topic. 200 million Europeans have a driving licence and almost every resident uses road transport. Traffic on European roads has tripled in the last three decades, infrastructure expenditure has increased, and there are still too many victims and human tragedies. And I think it is eri cuisine that the financial and social costs of the whole European Union cannot be calculated.  I am therefore very pleased that road safety is one of the European Commission's priorities. I am very much counting on the Commissioner's great commitment, which I absolutely do not doubt. I am very pleased that new technologies will be used in this process, because I think their impact may be what we once achieved with seat belts. It is also important to note the disparities in the number of victims in the various Countries of the European Union. Many people pointed out that there are more victims in poorer countries with less extensive infrastructure. I also hope that this topic will be taken into account in the Multiannual Financial Framework.  And of course, as someone said, "Education, stupid!". Without education, without indicating that we do not allow someone after drugs or after alcohol to get in the car, even the best resolutions will not help us to combat this scourge, to limit these tragedies. We therefore have hard work ahead of us, and I hope that, as the European Parliament, we will do it very well, which I wish all of us Europeans well.

name: Bogdan RZOŃCA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab This is a very important debate. The European Union, in many people's view, has a great deal of work to do here. Road safety, fatalities, long-term consequences of road accidents, compensation, pensions, medical expenses are simply a very shameful side of the functioning of the European Union. Although there is progress, we have a lot of work to do. I would expect, Commissioner, a fair report that compares the situation in different countries. It is no secret that most accidents occur in post-communist countries where road infrastructure is the worst. I therefore ask the Commissioner to ensure that there are no savings here, that you have the resources available for the ring road, for the expressways, for Via Carpathia, which runs through Romania. It is also necessary to make funds available to local authorities, which are able to make great use of money for those roads where there are the most accidents. I wish you good luck in this difficult mission!

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members of the House, I appreciate very much your comments and your interest for this subject. As I said from the beginning, only working together and putting enough pressure on all the stakeholders on which depends the safety on the roads, will we achieve results. You were mentioning, for example the targets. We have the targets which are expiring as I said, this year, and maybe one would ask why we would have targets if we cannot achieve them? But I do believe that having a target is an important instrument, an important tool, to design policies and enter into dialogue with the stakeholders in order to have a concrete vision for the future from various areas. So I myself I’m favouring keeping a clear target which can guide our action, and we can remember and recall all the time. We don’t need .... all of you mentioned the numbers, and I mentioned the numbers at the beginning, and I said and I want to repeat that actually any number is not acceptable. And that it was said it is also not acceptable that we get used to hearing about this and numbers of deaths on the roads. So that’s why clear action is absolutely needed, and we need to be committed to that. Several have mentioned the vulnerability of pedestrians or other categories involved in traffic. So when we talk about the safety of course the citizens have to be at the core of our action, and we have several categories of vulnerable road users. So we have also the pedestrians as were mentioned, but the cyclists, the motorcyclists are most at risk, especially in urban areas, and we are also looking into the urban mobility package to see ways in which we can improve the safety inside the city. The problem is, and we all know that where all the categories are meeting together, and now the evolution of the technology we see and the introduction of new ways of mobility in cities, I think these kind of risks are higher. So we have to work very early on devising a policy to accommodate all these categories which would meet in the same space. But since we are talking about that, let me refer also to a topic many of you raised. That technology and digitalisation can help us to improve road safety. Many mentioned the fact that we are looking at autonomous vehicles in the future, artificial intelligence - but this comes also with lots of challenges because we have to admit that at the beginning, all these vehicles, well slowly with the introduction of the infrastructure, will need to co-habit with the traditional ones. And this is also something we have to imagine from the very beginning as being a new risk for the safety on the roads. So this is another angle we are looking at. I’m very much favouring the Safe System as a system approach because it looks at all the elements which are making road safety challenging. Many of you mentioned driving licensing. We are looking into this and I think in 2022 we will come up with a proposal, somewhere mentioning the speed. Of course, speed is one of the most important elements, and we have also, let me give you another figure, an estimation from the EDFC, that only one kilometre per year reduction in average speed in the EU would already reduce the deaths by 2000 a year. So this shows that speed is a very important factor. We are also looking and analysing to see how we can convince and cooperate with the Member States in order to act in this respect. We know that in 2017 there was the Valetta Declaration on Road Safety and the transport ministers committed to engage on the possibility of reducing speed limits. So let’s see where we are after this with each Member State. Personalised analysis for Member States is done, and I encourage you to follow, and I’m sure you’re not already, but maybe we will have another chance to discuss the subject after the annual report and statistics, which is going to be published in April. And also I would like to commit with you that after the Stockholm Conference, I would have probably the next day I am in the TRAN Committee, and I can already report back to you on what was committed to in Stockholm and which are the next steps to be taken together with you in the future to increase road safety in Europe - and why not to the leadership for other continents, because we know and we have instruments and programmes for Asia and for Africa and would like to lead there, so that globally we can contribute to the reduction of deaths and serious injuries on the roads. Thank you very much for this debate and I’m as always at your disposal for this topic or others for discussion in the future.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. – Road safety is a subject that must be kept on the agenda on a permanent basis. Traffic accidents have many negative, often tragic consequences for individuals, families and the entire national economy. It is a fact that we have managed to reduce the number of traffic accidents in recent decades, but we cannot be satisfied until the number of such accidents continues to decrease. Unfortunately, in most cases, human factors, drink-driving and speeding are still to blame for accidents, so there needs to be an even greater emphasis on education and prevention. We need campaigns at European level to raise people's awareness of the importance of road safety. The technical condition of motor vehicles is also an important factor influencing it. Fortunately, technologies are now being installed in new vehicles that make a significant contribution to their safety and reduce the number of accidents. In a few decades, self-driving cars may become a reality, and then the human factor will be minimized and technical safety maxilmalized. But in the meantime, we must do everything we can to make transport safer on European roads, because all human lives matter.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. – Road safety must become a priority! This means, first of all, providing a wider space for this subject at European level, because it is about saving lives and actions that can and must be done together. I am concerned about Romania's road safety situation in Europe. Roads in Romania are perhaps the most dangerous in Europe. With almost 100 deaths per million inhabitants and almost 2,000 people who die annually from road accidents, Romania unfortunately fails to do anything concrete in this regard. A catastrophe! I call on the European Commission to act in this regard to develop a strategy in this area and to monitor in real time the efforts made by the Member States, because safer roads mean a safer life for European citizens!

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: I declare adjourned the session of the European Parliament.
